description:
This was an adorable café. I needed to find a place with a lot of seating, good drinks, and WiFi, so this place checked off all those boxes. I ordered a cup of tea, and the mug was pretty large (plus they allowed for free refills of hot water). A teapot is also only $6. 

There was a lot of space to sit, and the café is connected to a bookstore. Like other reviews indicate, they only have WiFi on weekdays until 5pm (I was there on a Friday afternoon so it was fine with me--the speed of the WiFi was fast as well)!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Me: "do you have wifi?"
Barista: "not on the weekends."

So, they have wifi, but decided that their weekend patrons should engage only in activities which do not require an IP address?  Flashback to my mom restricting my computer usage when I was in 7th grade.  Its upsetting now even more than before.  I guess that pretty much explains why nobody was there.  Will definitely take my mom here next time she is in town.  But only on a weekend.
author: Rory M.

description:
Strolling around at Valencia with a friend and colleague of mine - and we were both in for a coffee.. We found Borderlands and went inside.. Got a cute little table on the side, and ordered some coffee and some cookies.. 

A pretty nice place - I like the atmosphere! :)
author: Nadia S.

description:
One of the more unique coffee shops I've been to, mainly because it had a bookstore connected to it. While the bookstore wasn't the biggest, it's nice to see that old school book stores are still in the mix. 

Borderlands is a nice place to do some work and study on socialize with friends. But fair warning, if you're trying to study and can't stand noise than it's not the place for you. Luckily for me, noise doesn't bother me. So it's definitely a place I would consider studying in. There are outlets throughout the store and there are big tables all around. 

I only got a hot tea and chocolate chip cookie, both were adequate. I was told that my cookie was vegan so that's cool if you're into that kind of thing. For me it made no difference. Also, FYI they will refill your hot tea for free. 

The service was friendly and polite. So definitely a chill spot to spend your time at.

Oh, last part! They only take cash.
author: Juan Carlos H.

description: I have literally never encountered a meaner barista in my life. It was a man with bangs and he SNAPPED at me when I pulled out my card saying, "we are CASH ONLY!" He has the worst attitude I have ever seen for a barista, and I've seen some pretty mean baristas. This was a place that had no joy or kindness at it; I would not recommend it to anyone. The staff makes you feel bad for ordering anything.
author: Sophie Z.

description:
TL;DR Cozy cafe to do some reading (they're connected to a book store)

I got a latte, and it was so so soooo smooth and velvety. The milk was steamed perfectly and the espresso pull perfectly. There was no burnt or bitter taste at all. There are plenty of tables, big and small, for you to enjoy your coffee + pastries, by yourself or with some friends.

The only thing they could improve on is efficiency. I was first in line when I ordered, and people after me got their drink first. I was waiting near the counter looking at some post cards, and when I walked back over, I saw my drink half way made sitting on their counter. The staff were chit chatting and only starting making the drink again when they saw me walk back to the counter. If I were in a hurry, I wouldn't come here to get coffee.
author: Sophia L.

description:
What? Is this a remnant of Borders bookstore? Probably not, but remember that store? How does Barnes & Noble still have open stores? Anyway, this place is obviously not corporate America. It's a nice little Mission district cafe connected to a book shop that has lots of SF flavor. The coffee is not as sexy as Ritual Coffee Roasters, Philz, Blue Bottle, etc., but it gets the job done.

Borderlands serves tasty pastries, drinks, and wifi. Note that the wifi is cut off at 5:00PM. They have a few wall power outlets for those laptop junkies. This is not a bad choice for anyone who needs to get some work done.
author: Marlon T.

description:
I like to come here to do work every once in a while, especially when I want to get out of the "office".

The staff here is always super friendly and accommodating. I also like how there's a lot of space and light in here unlike other cafes down the street which are pretty depressing to be in after a while.

But with the extra space there's often a lack of seats so that's the rub. Luckily I almost always manage to find a spot during the times I go in the early afternoon.

Can't comment on the coffee since I usually order tea or a cocoa but this a good local cafe to support.
author: Art O.

description: Cash only. But don't let that deter you. One of my favorite weekend trips is getting coffee and a cookie at this place. There's usually plenty of seating, which is rare for San Francisco. It's attached to the bookstore, so you can easily peruse the stock before or after you order. The cafe is stocked with magazines and lovely succulents names for literary characters.
author: Bianca H.

description: When in San Francisco's Mission District, the most quiet, naturally lit, with lots of electrical sockets, and big tables for writing and reading "go to" spot: Borderlands Cafe. They consciously choose not to play music, so the only sounds are quiet conversations, pages turning, the barista calling out orders. I had a vegan peanut butter chocolate cookie--yum--and coffee. Both were comforting and delish on the day I worked there. They have light fare such as bagels (can get with pbj, butter, or cream cheese), vegan cookies, egg sandwiches, etc. The patrons are mostly regulars who hang out, reading, writing, perusing the periodicals. No phone convos in the cafe allowed (yippee!), and a clean loo for patrons. Bigger tables for sharing are in the back, while smaller cafe style tables dot the shop's front seating section. Their bookstore is adjacent and may be accessed from inside the cafe, selling both used and new books, note cards, and other bibs and bobs. Important: cash only establishment. It's how they keep the prices reasonable.
author: SR M.

description: Cool little hipster spot with an interesting bookstore built in. Lots of outlets and good wifi. The coffee was tasty and high quality. The only thing stopping me from being a regular is the wifi is only on limited weekday hours then shut off.
author: Sean G.

description: Great staff. The Mexican Hot Chocolate is fabulous. They only take cash, but there is an ATM machine in house.
author: Doug H.

description:
Charming atmosphere; great coffee and service!

Perfect space for grabbing a beverage or pastry to go, working, studying, or catching up with a friend. Plenty of outlets and Wifi on weekdays until 5pm. If you absolutely can't stand to be web-less, consider becoming Borderlands sponsors and you have access to their network all you want.

They also have an excellent magazine and greeting card selection. 

Cash only but there's an ATM inside, in addition to a Bitcoin ATM (!) .
author: Noa B.

description:
I was early to meet my friend for a movie at nearby Alamo Drafthouse, so decided to hunt for a cafe for a comforting drink on a rainy day and perhaps a sweet pick-me-up treat. I ended up with a hot chocolate made with soymilk and chocolate coconut cookie. Hello, sugar high! I expect a lot from cafes in SF since there is so much competition, and Borderlands' hot chocolate was adequately rich and sugary. The hot liquid warmed my body as I walked through the rain, juggling the cup and an umbrella. I thought I might eat half of the cookie and save the rest for later, but nope, all of it disappeared while I stood munching outside the theater. 

Of course, Borderlands' clever labels on bottles of honey and what I guess is agave syrup, "bee vomit" and "cactus sap", respectively, is a crowd pleaser. 

Alert: Borderlands is cash only.
author: Amy G.

description: A wonderful place to work with a coffee by your side. Friendly baristas churn out solid coffee in this unpretentious space filled with wonderful light and enough outlets to keep you plugged in for hours. It's my favorite place to hang out and work in the Mission. This place still feels like the Mission I know.
author: David A R.

description:
Great space for reading or working. The space is really nice. They have a diverse selection of teas & have Numi teas. They have a few food items, but it'd be great to see more food options. Also it's important to know they are cash only. 

The Borderlands bookstore is connected next door, which is nice. They also have a bunch of magazines available to read while you're at the cafe.
author: Mary L.

description:
Great Cafe, especially for a lazy or roaming Sunday. My favorite part is the library on the other side AND there was an author reading! I love author readings especially when the author is writing a comic-style novel. A good amount of outlets and tons of seating. Great coffee too. 

Side note: I came here on Sunday to study and unfortunately the Wifi was either turned off or just not working. (They have a sign in the front mentioning they turn it off after 5 on weekdays) i appreciate the no wifi zone when I don't have homework, but nevertheless I didn't need it for the work I was doing at the moment (I was doing math HW & I have my textbook saved as a PDF, so maybe do that before you come in, in case.
author: Acelia C.

description: I was visiting San Francisco recently and stopped into this cafe. The staff was so friendly. The space is big, open, and well decorated. Prices are reasonable.
author: Emily H.

description: If your idea of having a relaxed afternoon coffee is to chat on Skype in with a friend from a distant country in a foreign language, this is definitely not a place for you, because you will encounter many rolling eyes and a barista will kindly ask you to stop (even if you are nice and relatively quiet). If you want a quiet place to work or read, it is not a perfect place either, because there might be a workshop exactly at that time that would distract you from your work. So, this is neither a cafe nor a place to work. Expect very bad quality of the coffee. Also expect that if you are not a native speaker, every time you come, you will be asked "Where do you come from" and "Are you on holiday?", which is nice when you hear it for the first time, but very irritating if it keeps repeating and makes you feel very humiliated and unwelcome. I will never come again.
author: Selma T.

description: I came here on a Sunday morning and I was greeted by friendly staff! There are plenty of tables to sit at here, and it's one of the larger cafes that I have been at. I got an iced coffee, and it was nothing special. I probably won't come here to get an iced coffee next time and maybe try a latte instead, but I am giving this place 4 stars because it's a great place to study with hospitable staff.
author: Lynn T.

description: Here my standart one star goes to coffee places that have a weird wifi policies. No wifi at weekend, shut down after 5pm at weekdays? Well, if you didn't realize, I'm not here to drink your average latte and have microwaved and ruined breakfast bagel. I'm here to get some works done. If you can't provide this basic facility, I don't care what else you sell. Needless to say, it's cash only. Keep rockin this way guys ;)
author: Osman K.

description: Love the friendly staff and ample space to study. Wish they have some food menu but at the same time wish it doesn't get overcrowded. Haha can't be too perfect here on Valencia. Like them as it is and hope they survive for good!
author: Kylie H.

description:
As a sci-fi geek who enjoys smooth coffee and a mellow place to get lost in reading, I feel at home here. The staff is quirky and friendly, announcing orders with a thespian flair. The blond guy (the manager?) is really fun to talk to, helpful and nice to the staff and pretty much everyone.

As much as I like Wi-Fi when I lounge around in cafes, I appreciate that they keep it off during the weekends. You'd never get a seat if they had it on! Writers like myself can still do their thing. There's no music, but that's ok, I have earbuds and a smartphone. Oh yes, almost forgot, people don't talk on their phones and those with kids are respectful of disturbing others. Some of my friends pranked me once and called there asking for me and pretending to be Indrid Cold. Good times! 

I do wish they added bigger food options so I could get a more complete lunch. The piroshkis are good though and I usually break down and get a black and white cookie too. The bookstore is a gem, and I love that an indie place like this is still thriving. So, think of this place as a rare treat- a well-lit library that let's you eat, drink and peruse their magazines.
author: Harry T.

description: This is a great coffeeshop, airy, on Valencia, with a bookstore next to it. The place is perfect to work out of, as I've done so many times. BUT: WIFI is ONLY available during weekdays, not weekends. Ytho....'____'
author: Clint S.

description: This cafe only takes cash, and no credit cards even though it's 2018. They also shut down wifi service during weekends and nights. Come on guys, step into the future. The drinks are also just not that good. Go to Ritual Coffee down the street for better drinks.
author: Kevin G.

description: Happened to stumble into this place as I was roaming around the Mission. Pretty chill atmosphere, a ton of comfortable seating (in talking padded chairs), reasonable prices, and a quiet place to work. Only con I can see is they shut the wifi off at 5pm.
author: Nicole A.

description:
Wifi, plenty of tables, good natural light, and attached to a bookstore. Great spot to hang out a few hours and have a coffee (or chai, like I did). Chai was ok. A bit spicey, will probably go with a latte next time. :)

*Cash Only*
author: Steffan P.

description:
"You've got about 2 minutes," the barista said to me.

I came to Borderlands on a Thursday at 4:58pm, ready to get some work done, only to be told that the wifi shuts off at 5. Well, it's a good thing I only had to do some reading and didn't absolutely require an Internet connection. Otherwise it would have been a waste of a trip. I guess I should've checked the Yelp reviews before coming here.

I ordered an iced chai, which ended up being pretty watery. I've definitely had better chai elsewhere. The staff also wasn't particularly friendly. There were at least 4 or 5 of them gathered by the register chatting, and they all just stared at me as I approached the register. It was a little uncomfortable. Too many people working, not enough work to go around...

In addition, this is a cash only establishment. Okay, I get that you try to sell your drinks cheaper this way, but really? I definitely paid at least $4 for a watered down chai latte...

A plus is that it is a pretty good place to study. It's a quiet environment with a good amount of tables to go around. But, I expect higher standards for a coffee shop in San Francisco. How are you gonna stay open until 8pm and shut off the wifi at 5? Maybe consider keeping it on later for people who just get off work? And what kind of coffee shop in SF doesn't accept card...
author: Cheryl N.

description: Helpful and friendly baristas and cool coffee shop vibe. The cozy atmosphere, with folks both working and chilling, was such a nice change from the cold, minimalist look that is sweeping coffee chains. I ordered a cafe au lait and my friend picked a hot tea from their large selection. Prices seemed on par with most coffee shops, though Borderlands is cash only (with a note stating the policy is aimed at keeping their prices low). Baked good selection was minimal so we got pastries elsewhere. Overall, a great neighborhood cafe that is worthy of support. If in the area, I would gladly return.
author: Nina C.

description: Chocolate Mint tea and an extra helping of kindness tonight.  Hope to come back sometime soon to study; very inviting!!  Thank you!!
author: Anne G.

description:
This is a classic and old school book store with a cafe.  They still have the skeleton key for the bathroom and shut off the wifi after 5pm without music.  

There are a variety of teas, coffees, and drinks as well as bagels, pastries, and snacks to select from.  Service is friendly with ample seating to lounge around an work.
author: Jenny L.

description:
My standard one-star review for cash-only establishments that don't offer a surcharge-free ATM. 

"In order to keep our prices as low as possible, Borderlands Cafe is a cash-only establishment".

Yes, but by only providing a cash machine that charges $2.50 a pop, Borderlands is just passing on the credit card surcharge to the customers. So, someone's paying, it just isn't Borderlands.

I understand that people can plan ahead and bring cash from somewhere else, but cafes are in the hospitality business, and this situation seems inhospitable. 

Otherwise, this is a great place; I really enjoy it and this is basically the only thing I don't like.
author: Chris P.

description:
If your cafe doesn't offer coffee, pastries and an ambiance that's awesome enough to draw hundreds of people through the door every hour... offer free wifi. 

This place has not so great coffee, crusty old  cookies (all of which needlessly made gluten free) and a meh interior. 

Actually, when you're looking for free wifi, it's perfect. And their menu board promises in huge letters,  "Free Wireless." 

However, If you're a normal human like me you'll spend some money on their not so great stuff before you notice the tiny print: they shut off the wifi at 5. 

I'm all for boundaries around being connected to the internet.

But in a place that can't delight you with tasty and beautiful things, don't pretend to be so hipster cool that you offer wifi sometimes and not others. 


Wifi should be all or nothing.

This place serves everyday realness, just like the emails I hoped to answer had I not accidentally made the wrong decision about where to buy a dried out, disgusting and needlessly gluten free cookie.
author: Andy B.

description:
Greetings from Berlin! 
There was a time when I came here on an almost daily basis. The friendly staff, the serene atmosphere, and the sign that suggests cell phone people to step outside during calls. There was a writer's group meeting on Wednesdays, and a big arm chair by the window, facing busy Valencia from a quiet place. Next to it a commode, a little black book on top. People could leave notes. The book starts with a Pirsig quote. 

Thank you for being there, Borderlands. You were the source of many an inspiration. I miss you very much. 

Oh, and, oh yes... the pastries, tea, and coffee... all quite delicious.
author: Thomas A.

description:
Great quiet, cozy study spot tucked away in Mission district. I came in the morning on a weekday with some friends and was able to grab one of the larger tables but this place does fill up quickly so come early!

There was only one person working when I arrived, and he was the most friendly cheerful person ever. He explained all the different types of espresso drinks to my friend and let me smell different types of tea since I wanted a pot of tea. I also accidentally spilled a glass of water and he was there immediately to help me clean up.

All the drinks here are good. The espresso is strong, and the loose leaf tea comes in a very cute tea tray. I also got the pesto cheese bagel which is HUGE and will keep you set for an entire morning of studying/reading/etc. :)
author: Elaine W.

description:
Ah, Borderlands. You do my heart good! 

Stopped in yesterday afternoon, looking for a warm drink (15 years in the city, and I still hope summer will be warm!) and a quiet place to get some work done. 

The cafe was busy (a good sign!) with all manner of people you'd find on Valencia on a Friday afternoon. 

I was met with the three things you need in a cafe experience - great customer service, stellar drinks, and a welcoming environment. 

The baristas were super friendly, knowledgeable, and extremely patient with my awkward hemming and hawing at the counter over what to order.  They were working quickly, but were laughing with each other and their customers - not the surly service you get in some other cafes (I'm sorry I'm not as cool as you, Mr. Top-Knot!).

My drink was prepared quickly, was the exact right temperature and sweetness (I'm such a stickler for temperature - I hate a lukewarm drink, or an almost hot-drink that collapses into lukewarm before I've even gotten past my email inbox, and too sweet or not sweet enough is going to ruin my day) and delicious. I could have had three! 

Lastly - what a great spot. The ambiance is balanced - the sci-fi bookstore next door opens into the cafe, there's a well-appointed magazine rack (where you can borrow a magazine or two to read while you're sipping, as long as you return them to the rack when you're done!), big solid wood tables that beg for your laptop or paperback and another latte), free wi-fi, a giggle-worthy sense of irreverence in their signage, and it's quiet but not stuffy, cool but not pretentious. 

I'll be spending some working hours at Borderlands!
author: Kory O.

description:
1. wickedly awesome tea. 
2. peaceful place to work.
author: Danielle B.

description:
Lovely place. No cell phones, no music, no WiFi at certain hours. It's meant to be a more traditional cafe to relax and read a book or spend time with friends or just enjoy some coffee/tea/etc. It's also a nice place to do homework, especially if you don't want to be tempted to go online since WiFi isn't available all the time. There's a small outdoor courtyard out back that I find charming. 

I liked the teas that I've gotten while here. Not sure about the coffee because I don't drink coffee.

Oh, and they don't take credit cards, if I recall correctly. The sign says it's to keep their costs low, and I like that. 

Bathrooms: Solid. No complaints, except maybe that's there's only one unisex one, though maybe I missed another one? There's a gigantic thing attached to a key at the counter.
author: Jimmy H.

description:
My new favorite cafe on Valencia! Unpretentious, kind, and warm waitstaff; plenty of tables and even a cozy couch; and connected to a sci-fi bookstore, which although I didn't visit, gives it that good vibe only a bookstore connected to a cafe can offer! Pretty simple selection of tea, coffee, bagels and pastries, but the environment more than makes up for the slim food pickins. 

I got a pot of loose leaf tea and it came on a little silver tray with honey and cream dishes for me to fill up myself and take to my table. I loved it. Like being in England :)

Cool, local art on the walls, good lighting, big magazine rack (for sale, but fun to browse anyway). A great place to have a warm cup and a relaxed pause in the hipster strip of SF.
author: Taylor P.

description: Awesome place. Great coffee and bagels, nice and friendly vibe. First time here and I'd definitely come back. Good tables to do work, and really welcoming staff.
author: D H.

description:
Was mid-day and we desperately needed a wake-me-up coffee, so glad we chance upon this cafe.

A friendly neighborhood cafe that serves up awesome coffee. We had a latte and a ice latte, taste superb! 

Its a quiet and peaceful atmosphere, a perfect place to rest your feet and just slow down a little. People were working on notebooks as in pen and paper, couples reading together, kids drawing and just a handful on their laptops. Quite a rare sight honestly.

Just a small downside hence the four star instead of five - they do not accept credit. So remember to bring cash before swinging by. A wonderful place to do some reading, chill a little and just enjoy the mission.
author: Cindee T.

description:
After a yummy breakfast at Radish, my buddy and I walked over to Borderlands for a drink and time to talk about his new project.  They've got a variety of things on their menu and they all sounded good, so it took a little bit for me to finally decide.

I ordered the Mexican hot chocolate to sip on, and really liked the balance of chili and cinnamon in the cocoa.  I've had versions in the past that were a little too spicy, but like Goldilocks with her perfect bowl of porridge, this was just right.

Service was really friendly and helpful, and I love that there are plenty of places to sit and get work done.  Prices are very reasonable and there's lots to choose from on the menu.  I'd definitely pick it as a spot to set up since some of the cafes in the area aren't as friendly for those with laptops.  They can expect me back soon.

Food: 8/10

Service: 9/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 8/10
author: Joe M.

description:
This is a nice little spot in a very cool area.  The staff is friendly and they are pretty quick with drink orders.  Now, I will be honest, I did not partake in any beverages, but the three others in my party did and seemed to enjoy their orders: hot chocolate, espresso (with a shot of whipped cream), and a regular coffee.  

It is super helpful that they have the "rules of the roost" posted around and the seating was packed when we were there signaling to me that people really enjoy this spot.  We were able to find a table after a minute or two!

Also, take note, this a cash only establishment with an ATM.
author: Lauren R.

description:
Borderlands Cafe has become my daily coffee shop of choice!  In addition to continuing to serve The Best Iced Mocha in all of San Francisco (yes, I've been to Ritual, Philz, Four Barrels, etc., why do you ask?) in a clean, quiet, well-lit environment, one of the top reasons I continue to come here day after day is the service!  

The people who work here are AWESOME!!!  Friendly, quirky, fun, and really on point with maintaining a high level of service/quality of product, I always enjoy chatting with them when I come in to get my joe.  When they see me walk in, they start my beverage immediately, and it's usually mostly-made by the time I even get to the register!  And sometimes, if my partner or I are running late, we call our beverages in in advance so we can just rush in, pay, and leave immediately...because they know us and know we're good customers, they willingly do this for us!  That's FIVE-STAR service!!!

Other tasty things on the menu:  the meat and cheese plates are basic, tasty, and a good value for the money!  I usually get (and share!) the 3-meat and 3-cheese plate, which also comes with lots of french bread, delicious spicy brown mustard, and a little bowl of cherry tomatoes that are cold and refreshing!  That costs $11.  If you want only 2 meats/2 cheeses, that's only $8, and 1/1 for $5.

They also have a good selection of baked goods.  My favorites include the Raspberry cornmeal scones, linzer cookies (which are HUGE), peanut butter cookies, and the chocolate croissants.

They offer French Press coffee here.  Yum!  And sometimes they draw cute pictures on my coffee cup.  I love that!

Borderlands doesn't have Wifi.  On purpose.  There.  I said it. 

Why, you ask, incredulousness dripping from your tech-obsessed voice?  Well, they have this weird notion that people will use their cafe to interact with other humans ("talking" or "conversation"), read a book (maybe one from their sister store, Borderlands Books?), write a book (various writing groups meet here regularly), or generally use the time to disconnect from the internet.  Novel, I know.  Of course, if you have an internet dongle that gets you wifi anywhere, well, I suppose this isn't an issue for you, is it?  

There is a clean bathroom here.  That's good to know, right?

There is TONS of seating, including some very comfy upholstered furniture.  Nice for cuddling into with a good book...

Alas, Borderlands closes at 8 pm.  Sigh.  Yeah, I know.  Why do all the good coffee shops in the Mission close to bloody early???  They used to close at 9 pm, but according to the owner, they couldn't sustain staying open that last hour due to the low amounts of business that time of night.  I guess everyone foregoes coffee in favor of PBR?

Go here.  Try the Ice Mocha.  Seriously, it's delicious.  All my friends agree, too.  And bring the book you've been meaning to read/write.  Enjoy!
author: Amy L.

description:
Borderlands Cafe is a good place to get a cup of coffee, but a great place to spend time. 

The coffee itself is smooth and fresh, though is nothing fancy. However, the lounge area is perfect for studying, reading, or even just hanging out. It's a home-away-from-home for many people, and Borderlands knows this.
author: Casey S.

description:
Lovely little place with reasonable prices and friendly people.  The book selection is awesome and the general vibe is nice.  Great find as we were just walking around.  Nice place to sit down and work.

Update: the barista asked me if I wanted water when I just ordered latte.  So thoughtful!!!  I love this place man.
author: V V.

description: This cafe is fine if you only care about coffee, but is exquisite if you're looking for a place to post up and read or work for a while.  There's no music playing, which is just so very helpful for concentration.  There's also a pretty dorky vibe, which makes it seem pretty welcoming.
author: Kyle W.

description:
Coffee is ok, but there's a terrible selection of food. I think my bagel was microwaved :/
Internet is also hella slow.
author: Asaf N.

description:
I came here during a weekday afternoon.  So take my review with a grain of salt.

If you're alone, have your laptop, and like the volume level of a library, then this is the place for you.  If you were hoping to have a conversation with another human and didn't want 40 people eavesdropping, you might want to try a different place.
author: Matthew S.

description:
Weekend and evening workers beware: no WIFI after 5pm during the week or at all during the weekends.

If you are going between 9am-5pm, this place would be great because the atmosphere is awesome. But without wifi, the just-okay coffee doesn't make it worth it.
author: Julia C.

description:
If you don't mind sharing a table with a random stranger, then you won't mind this cafe. Most of the tables and comfy chairs were occupied when I arrived (approx 12:30pm). I had to look for a table with a nearby outlet, so I ended up sharing a table with a stranger. No big deal really; the table was big enough for the two of us. 

It was lunch time so I ordered a hot mocha and a spinach, roasted pepper and feta croissant. The mocha had the perfect amount of foam and had just the right amount of sweetness. I would give it a try if you're in need of a pick-me-up. The croissant was warm and flaky, but there didn't seem to be enough spinach and roasted peppers in my croissant. Oh well... it did the job. CASH ONLY here. Luckily, they have an ATM machine inside. 

There's free wifi here as well. Unfortunately, it automatically shuts off after 5pm even though the cafe itself doesn't close til 8pm. What a shame...can't come here after 5 to do work (online) then.
author: Zandra T.

description: Misleading establishment. They won't tell you that there are no seats and wifi is only turned on weekdays until 5pm after you've paid for your items.
author: Daniel C.

description:
worst service ever. it took them almost 30 minutes to fulfill our order and not all ordered drinks were prepared. we just left instead of waiting another 30 minutes for the remaining drinks they didn't write down and charge for the first time.

also, this place is cash only with an atm inside which of course charges an extra fee
their excuse is 'this is why our drinks are so cheap'
funny since the prices are almost 50% higher than starbucks... and the coffee wasn't that great either
author: Aram A.

description: It was a nice places to study if you find a place to sit. They have very friendly staff and great pastries.
author: Amy L.

description: Best place ever!  Love the atmosphere and the staff and most importantly the tea/coffee!  Not to mention the book shop next door!
author: R P.

description:
What a fantastic cafe! Reasonable prices for coffee and food. Free WiFi between 9 am and 5 pm. Lots of seating spaces and tables to spread out your stuff and get some work done. A few big comfy armchairs for sitting and reading. I love this cafe!

I got a pot of French press coffee for $4 (enough for 2 cups of coffee). Staked out a table and worked on grading my students' exams for the next 4 hours. Even though they closed at 8, they let me stay longer as they were cleaning up.
author: Elle P.

description:
Borderlands Cafe is next to borderlands books. nice modern looking cafe. didn't check the eats. ambience looks nice. everytable had a laptop on it.

brew: coffee (1.90)
-smooth, med body, fab drink
4 stars.
-french press (4) available

drips;
-just a coffee review, fab
-betten than javalenicia down the block.
author: Victor G.

description: The coffee is good, maybe great.  The café looks as if it's somewhere behind the iron curtain in the eastern block Prague or whatever, dimly lit yet with sufficient lighting.  The customers are quiet and the staff are serious about what they do, a bit bohemian snobby yet friendly as long as you don't ask for a Frappuccino.  They purposely do not offer Wifi in fear of becoming Starbucks or Peets.  I love these urban sole proprietor coffee shops whose staff are alt-whatever, a café establishment protected from chain store dominance by the local chamber of commerce Politburo - they have character to make up for unnecessary variety.  And it's not all just Sprockets hipster personality vibrations here - they back it up with flavor.  I had a nice, perfectly foamy heart design, almond latte.  Add to all this their awesome and unique bookstore next door with their anarchist newspapers and the sort and you have the recipe of why the Mission is an awesome Soviet place.
author: Khash C.

description: Super quiet, great ambience, free Wi-Fi, good coffee. Everything you'd want and expect in a cafe.
author: Melissa R.

description: Very crowded and they only have wifi on weekdays, which also they shut off at five. They don't particularly care if there are no spots for you to sit at.
author: Polina V.

description: This has got to be the most hospitable place in SF. Lovely little coffee shop, great biscotti, airy bookstore attached, friendly in letting people use their restroom, and just all-around homey and welcoming. Terrific neighborhood spot!
author: Rebecca C.

description: This is my favorite coffee shop in San Francisco. It has a charming but unpretentious ambiance (at least by SF standards), and prices are reasonable given the range and quality of the menu. No wifi on weekends a huge plus in my book. I whole-heartedly recommend Borderlands Cafe if you're looking for a place to connect with a friend, a book, or yourself!
author: Alexandra R.

description:
I'm not much of a coffee drinker. I'm more of a fan of the bookstore next door. My wife likes coffee though and we stop here sometimes when we're running around Valencia St.

I'm happy we were here though and not somewhere else on Memorial Day when I had one of the scariest experiences of my life and went into shock from extreme back pain (from what I later learned were a couple bulging discs in my back). 

As it was happening, the man working at the counter immediately came to help. He called 911 for us, brought me water, and soothed my nerves while my wife was dealing with the paramedics. The whole time he was extremely kind, professional, and respectful.

This was some customer service that I won't soon forget.
author: Christian M.

description: Beware their ATM! The cafe only takes cash (minus), and they have an ATM on site which charges $2.50 (minus as well), but when I did a balance inquiry before making a withdrawl, it finished the transaction after that instead of asking me if I wanted to do anything else, so then I was charged $6 by my bank for making two transactions. So I spent $8.50 in ATM fees for my $8 worth of coffee, instead of them taking on what would have been a $0.24 credit card fee for my two cups of coffee. I usually have cash but I just didn't today. Kind of a bummer. The coffee was fine. The people were friendly. Seems like a nice atmosphere but I wish there were a bigger cash only sign (if there even was one) so I could have saved myself $8.50 before they started making my coffees.
author: Bertha O.

description:
Borderlands Cafe holds a special place in my heart. I regularly make the 20 minute bike ride just to come hang out at the only coffee shop that I know of that doesn't feel the need to blast music at your head. That's right: no music is played in the cafe. And no cell phones use is allowed either. 

Ostensibly they sell food and beverages, but I come here to buy peace. 

It's peaceful setting makes Borderlands a great place to read or write. The wifi is only available 8 to 5, monday to friday, but I tether to do my homework at other times. 

The coffee is okay. The tea is great. The food is average. The atmosphere is unbeatable.
author: Jacob L.

description:
Loved this cafe.  The best coffeeshop environment I've encountered yet in SF... no annoying music and relatively quiet voice levels.  Very clean, modern, yet cozy space with a large variety of seating options (tables, couches, etc.) and lots of available seating.

The food is snack style (several options combining bread/cheese/salami, veggies with dip, pesto pasta, etc).  I had the North Beach sampler with bread, salami, mozarella & tomatoes in a basil olive oil marinade, and olives -- the ingredients were fresh and delicious!

Their mexican hot chocolate is kickass.  Cash only (they have an ATM) and no wi-fi.  Great place for reading, working without internet distractions, studying, board games, and conversation.  I hope to make it back during my visit to SF!
author: Ran L.

description: As far as coffee goes, this place just has adequate coffee. The baristas are friendly, and the space is very large (back and front areas to sit), but you'll be paying standard hipster prices for your brew (which is in a keep-warm container). I like all the books they have, but the couches aren't very comfortable (one long one in particular is just a wooden bench covered with a long towel/cover), and the people who are regulars here kind of creep me out.
author: Danny C.

description: I sometimes come here to enjoy a lemonade in the quiet, relaxed, bright atmosphere after perusing the bookshop next door.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Great atmosphere and super friendly staff! 

Really, after being in here for 4 hours and seeing the staff change, the lunch rush come and go etc I'm frankly offended by the less than 4 star reviews I've read. On the plus side if you think people who aren't wearing business attire are hipsters and you can't deal with sharing a table in a coffee shop then it's good you aren't here anyway.
 
Lots of outlets and a pretty good number of tables. The big tables are shared but there are also a few smaller ones.

Good coffee, good pastries etc.

The biggest thing is that the staff are super super nice and helpful. It's also clean and comfortable. All big pluses. 

Yes, if you want a big table to yourself then a coffee shop isn't for you anyway. Prices seem pretty good, $2.75 for coffee which is a tad less then I pay for good coffee in Berkeley. 

The crowd ranged from young to 80+ (I'm guessing on those two older folks, maybe they are younger but smoked a lot). Pretty quiet, a sign that says "You will enjoy your cell phone conversation more outside" and things like that.
author: Dan B.

description:
For the last two weeks, I have really been discovering what this sentence from Mark Twain means!
"The coldest winter I ever spent was a summer in San Francisco."
Especially when it's cold in the city and at the same time you have problems with your wifi connection at home! There are those days when you really need to go and hole up a warm cafe and do your work on your computer with a good wifi connection. But a lot a cafes in San Francisco, during the day, leave the door open and it's freezing cold!!! At the moment, I have to admit, that I don't understand this habit..... I have tried out alot of cafes so when I found the Borderlands Cafe I was so happy! They close the door and the window when it is cold and wet outside! So smart ;-)
And that's not all: the cafe is really great! Calm, quiet, clean, good tea, cheerful staff. And there are newspapers and books available. So from now on, when the wind is strong and the fog is over San Francisco, I will definitely go to this Cafe, where you can drink your tea, work, read without falling ill because of the currents of air! Thank you!
author: Natalia G.

description: Awesome place!! All you need is a good book! They also have great vegan cookies. There was an obnoxious girl talking on the phone when I got there and one of the baristas kindly ask her to take her phone call outside. I loved it!
author: Sol V.

description: The only place I know of in SF that feels like a warm library study with a lovely selection of cafe snacks. I have come here to draw things and work on freelance jobs. It's at a great central part of Valencia district so I 100% understand limited wifi use here, this place would get over run by tech savvy folks and probably does anyway at times. So many places refuse use of wifi (such as four barrel) because the establishment doesn't want it to turn into an "Internet cafe" duh!! At least your iPhone comes with a hot spot ! I don't really get why people will hate on a cafe for such a reason.. Love you Borderlands, I'm thankful you still exist and stay true to the good vibes of book worm society.
author: Adriana S.

description: YES. This place has elevated its status to possibly be my favorite cafe in not only the Mission, but SF as a whole. That's right. I said it. Why? Because they have wifi from 9-5 (to cater to the work crowd), but otherwise, no wifi and it is COMPLETELY silent in there. So, for all of the book/quiet time purists out there (including myself), you get the treat of hanging out at a quaint cafe adjacent to the bookstore and the majority of the time it's 100% silent in there. As I'm typing this, I'm already contemplating my next trip over there...
author: Mel G.

description: Pleasant experience. Regular drop brewed coffee is up to par. Large cinnamon roles are large and good for the price(brought in from a local bakery...as they told me). Atmosphere is charming and modern. Nice bookstore attached.
author: Matthew F.

description: I immediate fell in love with the cafe. Not only did they have sturdy wooden tables and incredibly friendly staff, but they allow you to bring your drinks into the bookstore! They also post all kinds of friendly reminders around the store as well as their thoughtful, gracefully rendered mission statement. Love!
author: Beth F.

description: A poor selection of books, snotty staff, and no internet. No cafe in SF should be in business without it. Luckily I can use my hotspot, so have at you snotty sons of baristas! :). Also only a few pastries as far as food in concerned.
author: Keith R.

description:
Delicious raspberry lemonade, but first and foremost great customer service and quaint quiet atmosphere that smells of books, which always relaxes me !

The cafe doesn't seem to play music, which I find nice, because no two people have the exact same taste in music. And for working on the computer and reading, silence is preferable.

Good spot to do a little work.
author: Alyssa R.

description:
Stopped in here for the first time recently and was impressed by both the food and the incredible bookstore to which it's attached. Coffee is good, atmosphere is pleasantly quiet and friendly. Staff are knowledgeable and attentive. The menu includes a variety of cheese and/or salami plates, as well as a selection of veggies and olives. They also offer a wide variety of high-quality deli sandwiches and some baked goods. We had the hot & spicy platter, which includes spicy capicola and soppressata, as well as a hot brown mustard, sriracha, and Crystal hot sauce for dipping. We also had the small cheese plate, on which the smoked gouda was a standout. 

Though it will be a plus for some, their lack of wifi presented a huge stumbling block for me. I needed to work on a number of tasks that all required web/cloud connectivity, so I had to cut my time there short. If looking to chat with a friend over a latte, or to curl up with a good book, or to work on something with no distracting internet connection, this place would be great.
author: Cage H.

description:
A café that's attached to the bookstore of the same name, Borderlands is a super-cozy, quieter place where the more muted, but by no means silent, volume and no-wifi-environment is actually conducive to productive work, conversations, or games. The coffee and pastries are all quite good and reasonably priced, the interior has a variety of couches, loungechairs, and tables, the staff are super friendly, and the overall ambience is clean and warm - right down to the bathroom, as others have mentioned. 

Given the many choices for coffee up and down Valencia and in the broader neighborhood, Borderlands holds a niche of its own. Yet another good choice in the Mission.
author: Vincent L.

description:
I stumbled upon this coffee shop on a beautiful day off. Me and a friend were trekking down Valencia with no plan, really. Well, technically, I really wanted to find a coffee shop I haven't been to before and Borderlands Cafe happened to be the perfect spot! 

I've noticed the cafe was very quiet which was very helpful because it's relaxing! Good for people who are looking for a place to take time with their coffee or to get some work done. 

The baristas were very personable, energetic, and helpful. 

The cafe itself is pretty huge with simple decor and a magazine stand that offers free read to customers! And did I mention it's connected to some kind of bookstore??? Score.

& of course, the coffee was very good. Great place.
author: Lisa K.

description:
This place makes you feel at ease. 

Unpretentious staff. 
Warm and friendly, tidy, living-room feel. 
No distracting music. Just the sounds of quiet chatter and espresso bar.
author: J L.

description:
Great place to do some work while drinking coffee. Large space with plenty of outlets. Best of all, the people are so friendly! Excellent customer service! 

I'm visiting from Chicago and I had a horrible experience at the java supreme close by...I was starting to think I was going to dislike San Francisco altogether. But Borderlands came to the rescue! Such a peaceful, relaxing, and accommodating place. I'll definitely be back!
author: Karina V.

description:
In my opinion, this is one of the lamest coffee shops I've ever been to. Actually you know what, this IS the lamest coffee shop I've ever been to.

If your attracted to the "I'm smart, studying, upscale, hip and cool, but I'm actually a socially incapable closet troll that controls everything I can to prove my authority" vibe, then this is your spot!! 

One of the most sterile environments ever.. It feels like a doctors office, not a damn coffee shop.. THERE IS NO MUSIC!!! Not even quite elevator music.. wtf...  I get the book store is connected, (which the bookstore is awesome) but god damn, connect the awesome book store to an awesome coffee shop not this place. What a waste. 

Oh yeah, no wifi after 5pm. Sorry, but I would hate to be an acquaintance with whoever the owner is.. 

I don't know how people rated this place highly...

Oh yeah, the coffee sucked too. I'd choose starbucks over this place any day, and that's saying a lot.

SO TO SUM IT UP:
If you wanna go study or read a book in a sterile, dead silent, no music, no atmosphere, no wifi environment, then come here guys. You'll love it.
author: Lark B.

description: My stop for coffee was great. Quick line for an acceptable bathroom, $1.90 for freshly brewed coffee (truly fresh, I had to wait a couple minutes), very friendly baristas who seemed to be having fun, and a cute pleasant atmosphere.
author: Dana G.

description: my "stuck in san francisco for the day and want a cool place to work and get tasty drinks" place.  Plus, they have books and Valencia orange "grown-up" soda.
author: Kate Marie G.

description:
I came back to Borderlands Cafe today after moving away from SF a year and a half ago. It used to be my favorite spot. PB wheat bagel and an Americano every weekend to study by. Got know some of the staff and always felt really relaxed. It never bothered me that there was no internet back then because there were (and still are) other cafes you can go to if you really need internet that badly. 

The PB bagel and Americano continue to be great! A guy I've never met was working, but he was all about friendly service. Checked to see if I wanted more water in my Americano (they use an appropriate amount of water instead of just filling up the cup, which is part of what makes it so good, so I recommend drinking what they offer you the first time). Then when he brought my bagel he asked if it was toasted enough (it was, but clearly if I wanted it black, he would've popped it in longer). Finally, he said to just say the word if I wanted more PB or some jam. 

The fact that they have Internet from 9-5 now is really nice. They never wanted to be the kind of place where people sit facing their Macbooks all day, so it's clearly a compromise, which I hope peeps can just understand and respect.
author: Emily B.

description: Super friendly staff, perfect if you want some quiet me time. Amazing collection of periodicals all free to browse. Love it!
author: Helen L.

description:
Friendly service and affordable prices, I just happened to order the Mexican hot chocolate (it is coco de mayo weekend after all) and later read other reviews where yelpers rave about it...they're right, the best Mexican hot chocolate I've had in a long time! Will be coming back again. 
Tables were all full but customers are also welcome to use the seating in the used bookstore attached to the cafe.
author: Daniella O.

description:
This is an incredibly unusual coffee shop because it's so peaceful. No cell phones, no music. This may sound rather dour but it's actually extremely calming and relaxing. And its catching. No yelling on cell phones or loud conversations. 

Also great coffee, food, and super nice people working there. 

Who could ask for more?
author: anna w.

description:
The Mexican hot chocolate has amazing chocolate. However, they should work on their spice mix- way too much cayenne and not enough flavor development from other spices. 

That being said, the interior is very calming, bright, open, and airy. The service is kind and considerate, if a bit enthusiastic at times. Good people though- I feel like I can trust them to touch the food I'm going to eat. Overall a good place to get some grading done :)
author: Nagma M.

description:
Stepping into Borderland Café feels like crossing into a tranquil alternate universe, a place far removed from the noise and chaos of the Valencia Corridor. At its heart, Borderlands is a writers' cafe. Its main attraction is the distraction-free workspace it provides. There is no wireless internet, no throbbing music, no sounds other than the unobtrusive white noise of hushed conversations. 

This is one of the last places in the city where you can get a cut of brew for under $2.00. Don't expect the world of the coffee--it's decent, but if you're looking for caffeinated perfection, you can brave the line at Ritual or Philz. However, if you are seeking a place to work on your latest masterpiece of speculative fiction, this is an ideal Mission oasis.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Fantastic place to sit down and read. Usually pretty quiet and they have a fantastic selection of coffees and teas and soft drinks. And their couches are fantastic.

This would be a 5 star place in my book but it loses 2 stars because of how loud the kitchen is when they're cleaning up. Everyone is speaking in low voices and being quiet, but around 6 the guy in the kitchen is tossing utensils in containers and washing stuff and banging pots and pans without any regard for keeping it relatively quiet. Maybe a partition should be added or something because it is loud beyond belief.

Kitchen sounds are only second to obnoxiously loud conversation on the scale of things that really kill the reading environment. It's like how loud a Starbucks would be if there were no conversation to mask the mechanical sounds. Other than that, when the kitchen is silent, it's a great place.
author: Mark B.

description:
As a writer, I cannot support Borderlands Cafe enough. And neither can you. Go there. Now.

Borderlands and their adjoining coffee shop of same name is a science fiction/fantasy-themed bookstore in the Mission with a read-friendly coffee bar inside. This unabashedly geeky (and I mean that in the most loving way possible) store draws the opposite crowd you'd expect from the Mission, dialogues between well-read genre enthusiasts abounded all over the store, and there were no hipsters in sight.

The helpful and knowledgable staff took the time to greet everyone and offer tours to groups who stopped by to visit. If you prefer your books in book form, do yourself and the industry a favor and stop by Borderlands Cafe!
author: Kevin B.

description: As one of SF's oft-maligned "MacBook in the cafe" demographic, I'm often hesitant about cafes in the Mission, since many of them seem to tend towards the tiny, hipster, and obscenely overpriced. Borderlands strikes a perfect balance between the worker bees (tables and outlets aplenty, cheap food and drinks) and the more traditionally inclined (WiFi only during working hours, cash only). Would definitely come again, if only to sample the strawberry lemonade they were sadly out of this time.
author: Cody W.

description:
5 stars for the Really friendly staff and comfortable atmosphere (not pretentious). 
3 stars for the coffee and pastries. Meh it's not bad, but not great. It's the convenience, chill atmosphere, and consistently kind staff that keeps me coming back.
author: Chelsea D.

description:
This is my favorite place to work in the city, hands down.  The atmosphere is great: bright and airy, nice tables, friendly staff.  They have a great loose-leaf tea selection; you can get a nice-sized pot for 5 bucks (I recommend the Naraka Assam).  Plus, the pastries are good and there's a nice set of cheeses.

Seriously, I've tried to work all over the place and there's nowhere else that even comes close.

To top it off, you can reward yourself with a great SF book from the connected bookstore (go with Jude's recommendations).
author: Charles O.

description:
Simple cafe that is an ideal place to read, write, study and enjoy space and some beverages and snacks. You won't find any fancy or complex menu, but when you're tired of all the other cafes being overloaded with people and noise, escape to here. I loved the couches toward the back of the cafe and the bright light coming in from the windows. 

Thanks for making a place like this.
author: Theresa S.

description:
I love it here. Definitely my favorite coffee shop in the neighborhood for studying and reading. 

Usually pretty quiet with the occasional people having normal level conversations. Everyone always goes outside to use cell phones. The guys that work there are all extremely friendly and the coffee is nice and strong. 

A lot of open space with a good mix of tables and couches. Also free current magazines for reading.

Whats there not to like?
author: Angelo S.

description:
Will keep this review short and sweet. 

Really nice location. Came here after Boba Guys was closed one day. Love the fact that they had a bookstore in here and tons if seating. 

I only had the spicy apple cider and it was delicious. 

Clean, friendly and quick. Just the way I like my coffee shops.
author: Winny F.

description:
Good:
- place is spacey and airy. A lot of tables to sit. Clean!
- located in bookstore

Bad:
- No credit card accepted "due to credit card processing fees". Are you gonna require me to pay in gold nuggets next time? 
- Wi-Fi during 9am -5pm during weekdays only. Are you kidding me? Dont tell me you hired someone to produce internet access for you manually during those business hours 
-  Place has no own identity. Every freaking menu or announcement on the wall laser printed in same boring MS Office San Seriff font. You feel like you are in the Office. 
- No fresh bakery items except few elderly looking croissants.

The worst:
- Watery coffee product combined with flat over burned milk- no foam completely! In this place  they called it "cappuchino". If you dont know how to make one here is recipe. The Espresso is poured into the bottom third of the cup, followed by a similar amount of hot milk. The top third of the drink consists of milk foam; this foam can be decorated with artistic drawings made with the same milk, called latte art.
author: Victor B.

description:
This place is overrated.

The starting point for any coffee shop is the coffee. And unfortunately, the espresso really was no good. Next, and despite the store being almost entirely empty when I was there, there's no wifi on the weekend. And finally: make sure you bring your headphones... unless you enjoy listening to impassioned critiques of the latest Star Trek movie (which I actually thought was pretty good).
author: James A.

description:
Favorite cafe ever. Since it's associated with the SciFi/Fan bookstore, I've always thought of it as a "nerd cafe" and a home-base of sorts, but now it seems a lot more hipsters and techsters have started to frequent it *scoff*

Anyway.... They have an excellently wide drink selection, with many loose-leaf teas, and even non-caffeinated drink options such as fancy sodas. I do a version of the paleo diet, which means I don't eat pastries, so I love the fact that they have a selection of real food, including meat and cheese plates. Every time I have ordered one and asked for no bread they have immediately offered to add extra veggies in instead. Wonderful customer service. Also, not only do they actually know what a "breve" latte is, they actually list it on the menu!

Some complain that there's no wireless, but frankly I'm glad for that, since it means you don't get mobile-office commandos parking all day. They do still have lots of tables and easily-accessible plugs, which means I bring my laptop there anyway to work on writing without all the distractions of the internet.

FYI they hold the special readings/signings for the bookstore in the cafe now, which means sometimes the tables at the back of the store are taken down and it might be a little crowded/loud, but that's usually only a couple times a month for a few hours on a weekend afternoon.
author: Colleen O.

description:
Tried it again against my better judgement, but during wifi hours because I needed to work on some work. I had to wait for a seat to open up and then when I sat down and opened my computer I discovered their wifi was down. 

Frustration nation over here.
author: Maggie F.

description: This place is really creepy. There are funeral parlors at 3 am that are more lively than this. And management--were they trained by the Gestapo? They sure act like it. Seriously they act like they are running the Third Reich and not a cafe. But my biggest objection is really the creepy atmosphere, It is like a room full of dead people without the rouge make up.
author: Bill B.

description: The coffee and pastries here are good. It's a nice calm place to do work, especially if you don't need Internet (the wifi only works mon-fri 9-5).
author: Haley K.

description: Borderlands is my favorite café to do my writing and other work during business hours. They have wifi from 9-5 M-F, and it's quiet and full of other people working hard. Staff are extremely friendly and remember you if you come regularly. The beverages and food are not fancy specialty brands, but they will keep you fueled and caffeinated while you plug away!
author: Denise B.

description:
I visited when Jessica Hahn-Taylor's work was up. Here is what I wrote in response to it with reference to the place. 


I hear nothing in Jessica Hahn-Taylor's work. 
No trains, no empty sighs, no adventure taken. 
But you have to understand 
Where I am coming, this man, 
For whom a quiet life in desperation 
Projects onto the pictures a glossiness 
That cannot enfold the risk.

I am at a crossroads, 
Almost crushed by Thoreau's words, 
Can barely breathe, 
This escape, my arm and head had given me. 

Like the concussion I received, 
The gift will be hoarded and then forgotten. 
Like all the rest, where love's lost eyes have rolled inside, 
I am the Nowhere Man, 
At peace before a meal of vegetables 
Touched but not for long. 
In view of men, as it is assumed, it is the women who go off and do.

It is painful, 
This arm and head cannot compare, 
Where just today I heard: 
"Women want a man whom they know 
"Is desirable to other women," 
Not alone.
It seems in a shallow pool, I swim.

What little dreams, we act, 
Pen in tablets or memoirs that sit in imaginary bookstores?

I am there. 
My book, my easy chair, which is nothing but a wooden stool. 
Always in a white room, with one window at best, 
Cockroaches as pets.

I see Dostoevsky's Raskolnikov waiting for his landlady.
She never phones. 
Instead, husky men, come at odd hours with guns. 

I remain, somehow. 
Breakfast is a slice of bread. 
There is always water. 

No, this train speaks of something more than what I've got. 
The plate of dreams - my hand held out - 
Is the easiest to clean?

No these dreams are not mine. 
I fear heights. 
My arm does not provide. 
My head makes stars spin when I lay. 

I see Bernd and Hilla Becher's water towers, 
Inner city graffiti, 
Train tracks, 
And seemingly single men in smaller spots. 
But, they are as desperate.

It comes to me why my mom is sick. 
She is lonely and depressed. 
These things kill her. 
Not cigarettes or coffee. 
What races the heart this much, but sadness?

I understand. I live it. 
It is a simple question:
Do you stay alive in the same spot where you slept and woke?
You must have family 
And friends, 
Just in case they are willing to help. 
Other than that there is no one. 

I see Edward Kienholz's Sollie 17
Depicting a "Dingy hotel room
"Harboring an elderly man
"In underpants 
"His face replaced by a framed photograph.
"In three poses,
"He Listlessly waits."*
Over and over again,
The lonely house on flat land,
The snow, 
The fire in the kitchen,
My blanket and tea,
Correcting students' papers.
I have no one to love
Only my books,
Thoughts - 
Hunger always growling.

The last time I had human touch, 
It was my physical therapist,
Put her fingers in my shirt,
Pressed her hands into the open wound,
But, I did not cry.
I only wanted to.
She smiled amid the awkwardness,
Not knowing I smiled out of shyness.
My breath was bad.
I did not turn toward her.
Our conversation was like two boats,
I starboard, and she port.
One gives the green light and the other turns red.

Her ring was a give-away, 
But I ignored it.
At the outset, she entered reception.
Speaking to a man in a walker, 
Whose wife was not happy.
Kissing her life goodbye, 
The woman was looking down the road, 
Where marriage was a tangled vow.
In days, she would use Craigslist,
Wreck romance with a homeless man.
The hopeless road beneath a television
Was not what she had in mind.

Instead, it was me she found again.
Knowing the PT was off limits
I accepted this empty lady.
In a café, crudite and chai,
We talked about the last carrot.

I said I would give it to her.
(She smiled.)
It wasn't long before the transition,
And it was he who was homeless.
Old folks home for the middle aged.
All of us in a mid-life crisis.

I knew it wouldn't last.
It only takes one wrong word
For the guilty to flail.
She flapped her wings and pushed me out.
On the curb, as suburbia's pedestrian,
I got unfriendly glares,
And more loneliness.

The police would come there too
As if they could smell a leper from 
A healthy glow.
No Burberry, no tux,
Just unwanted human flesh.

I don't know how it ended.
Like my concussion, one tends to forget.
My sister called it being "refreshed."
My mother toward the end
Repeated the question,
But no one wanted the answer.


*Taken from Oxford Dictionary of American Art and Artist, by Ann Lee Morgan, 2008, Oxford University Press.
author: Mario S.

description:
By far the best cafe in San Francisco. The atmosphere is great, the coffee is exquisite. There is a great deal of attention to detail on every aspect of the cafe (the bathroom key is on a length of copper pipe; copper has natural anti-microbial properties. Clever.) Good selection of food and pastries. They don't mind if you flip through the magazines for sale (a small sign explicitly offers them). The bathroom is the cleanest I've ever seen at a cafe or restaurant. I suspect the 100 score from the health department is because they cannot officially give a higher one.

There is no wifi at the cafe, which is why I come here when I need to actually get work done on my laptop without the tempting distraction of Internet cat videos. There are times when I move to a different cafe to access the Internet, but I wish more places were like Borderlands in this regard.

Best. Cafe. Ever.
author: Al S.

description: I do love me a coffee shop environment. Very homey, nice decor, not to mention the cafe is attached to a bookstore. However, the barista mixed up my order and seemed slightly annoyed when my friend and I took condiments back to our table. The croissant was great, but I'm not sure about the service.
author: Sherry C.

description: Very friendly service, but coffee is so important to me. My drink of choice is an Americano and theirs was at best watery and bland. Sad, because it's right next to a cool sci-fi fantasy bookstore, but I'll have to give this one a pass next time.
author: Jori K.

description:
Pros: Lovely, warm atmosphere and decor, friendly service
Cons: Kind of pretentious vibe and moody signage, no wi-fi, and, worst of all, I ended up tossing out my coffee it was so bad and buying another one down the street. I think maybe the cream was left out too long and got rancid? Only explanation I can come up with as everyone else seems to be gushing about it. Anyway, yuck. And man, I needed that coffee!
author: Jon G.

description:
great, fun place to get some work done if you'd like to sit down with some coffee and have an abundance of pastry options to choose from for snacking. 

tips:
cash only (to keep prices low, which they are!)
no wifi on weekends (although you could probably leech from random wifi networks nearby).
author: Tuwie N.

description: The magazine selection is completely ace, so even without the bookstore attached, this cafe would be quite novel (ha). The staff is awesome - and by staff I mean that one Peter Pan dude who I guess just lives there, because he's the only one I've ever interacted with (there are usually others dithering about but I'm starting to suspect they're just for show). But he's brill so no complaints. Drinks always decent.
author: Paige L.

description: Update: they're not closing after all! The community rallied together to with annual sponsorships to cover the loss they would have incurred with the min wage increase. Huzzah!
author: Alice C.

description: Of all the phenomenal coffee joints in the SF Bay Area, this one is slightly lower on the totem poll. I tried the latte which was good but not great. Unfortunately they are cash only so in order to even order something here, I had to have my friend pay for me. They have all the basics for coffee drinks, but nothing too unique or special to set them apart. I really liked the atmosphere and the baristas were incredibly friendly. Yes, I think A-Ok pretty much sums it up.
author: Kim S.

description:
This place is the real coffee/snack spot for people in the know. "Oh let's go to the Mission and get coffee" people say. "Let's got to 4B or whatever" These people are newbies who have no idea. The real scene. The real cool kids. The real cyber goth sci-fi babes with messed up green dyed hair are here. Plus the food is great and inexpensive, the service is full of nerds, and the signage in the store is verbose. 

Also you can read all the magazines if you put them back nicely and are not a giant prick about things. 

Also go next door and buy yourself a crazy book. Read it and be awesome, or just put it somewhere in your room and appear awesome.
author: Jason L.

description: Amazing couches, great lighting - feel like i'm reading in my grandma's dining room. Loved it. Oh, and super sweet staff. Unfortunately they did mess up the order.. no offer to fix.
author: Denise M.

description: Very chill place and the staff made me feel right at home. Lots of places to work and a good cappuccino topped with a smile.
author: Christopher J.

description:
Octavio Paz and Mexican Hot Chocolate. The former I picked up in their bookstore, the latter I ordered just to be a total caricature and as an ode to the Mexican Nobel laureate whose essays I held in my hands. 

What an experience! The total silence, with the occasional whirr of the espresso machine, helped. Everyone else here seems really zen. They all had big, noise-canceling headphones on (not sure why now that I think of it, there was barely any noise) and those in the plush seats sat with an ankle resting on the opposite thigh, reading slick-looking artists' books. But the fact that I showed up in running attire and promptly sprawled across one of their two open couches was fine. Their decor reminds me of a beach house minus the tacky. Their giant typed menu was very helpful. Sometimes neon chalk chicken scratch IS impossible to read when it's mounted a mile above your head.

The servers here are so nice. The lady who made my drink very sincerely wished me a good day when I left. I will be back. Next time I'll bring my work and order a latte. I'm sure it will be just as fitting.

(Minus one star because wifi would be helpful. I understand the desire to maintain a reading space, hey, it might encourage people to write more positive Yelp reviews on site.)
author: Cathy H.

description: Cute place, nice drinks and delicious cookies. Staff is nice and place can get lively  around 6. Connected to a cool bookstore. Get the raspberry lemonade and a mystery book!!
author: Cynthia G.

description:
This place is the annex of Borderland Bookstore next door. This has become my regular stop after the gym. They have local organic coffee but what I usually get is the iced jasmine tea. 

The decor reminds me of a library: hardwood floor, tables of various sizes, including an escritoire. That it has no wi-fi really creates a nice, quiet atmosphere for reading and working. Staff is always nice.

Updated 3/13/13  Borderland now offers free wifi Monday thru Friday from 9 to 5. I hope this place doesn't turn into like Cafe 780 which, of course, has been closed because of the laptop campers who occupied their tables all day.
author: Matt Y.

description:
I really like this place, for the very reason why people writing bad reviews hate it: it has no wifi on the week-end. And it's awesome. You can go there, sit down and have a quiet chat with a friend. Or read a book. Crazy huh?
So yes, that's very different from lots of other coffee shops in the Mission, it's not a place to bring your laptop on the week-ends, and I guess that's the point of them not having wifi at that time. Gives you a chance to be disconnected for a while, and that's nice.
Not sure about the coffee, I only had tea and it was ok - nothing amazing. What matters to me is the quiet, peaceful vibe I get there.
author: Sarah B.

description: There are many cafes in SF -- but Borderlands is a destination. Authors have incorporated it into their novels -- 'known people' stop by here on frequent occasions. Coffee is not as good as say, Four Barrell, but is still very good. Very work-able with stable wi-fi.
author: Valentin B.

description: why is this place always full??? Food(pastries)suck and are completely overprices (8 bucks for 2 pastries!?), no wifi on weekends. WTF? Why is this place even in business? This cafe is the epitome of a rip off typical SF cafe.
author: Happy C.

description:
I work in the Mission and this is my favorite coffee shop in the area. Other places in the neighborhood look cooler and have hot baristas but I really don't give a shit about those things. The coffee is good  and they have a nice selection of breakfast items. The people there are very friendly and attentive and there are plenty of cozy places to sit. My favorite part is that it's attached to a book store and they have a magazine stand with some great choices. 

The only problem is they are cash only, which I really don't mind.
author: Raquel L.

description:
I walk past 20 other coffee shops, including 4 Barrel and Ritual, to go to Borderlands Cafe. They have the best steamed milk drinks ever! Mocha, Latte, Cappuccino, Hot Chocolate etc. 

There are also giant tables, real live plants, pleasant lighting and a great magazine news stand.

Also FOOD. Veggies and dip, cheese and salamis, and pastries.

If you really need Internet you should bring your own with you.

My only gripe is that they aren't open a little later. Not that I have tried more than 2x to go there after 9pm but dammit I want to!
author: Becky H.

description: Really sad since mission creek closed. How to find another studious library type cafe? I like the quiet ambience of this place though. A little hard for an adjunct to do grading on weekends  since they don't have wifi on weekends (these days grading is all online) but it is nice during the week.
author: Carrie H.

description:
Pretty awesome.
Warm inside, nice cheerful service.  They have a variety of legit teas.  I got the PG Tips decaf which was pretty good, but was hella hot forever.  My friend liked their apple cider.
author: Xue H.

description: Like to read a little sci-fi while you take a swig of java?  Well, Borderlands is the place to be.  I'm a fan of the Mocha.  Everyone speaks of the Mexican Hot Chocolate, but I need a little caffeine to make things interesting.  A good place to bring your laptop for some email, work or study.  Cash only.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
I really like the people who work here, the coffee (with the agave nectar available), and the atmosphere. The reason I even walked in here with my boyfriend is because the guy working behind the counter (whose name I never got) had waved to us from afar. It was so nice to be greeted that way, that we decided to go inside and get a bagel and coffee. The people who work here are super friendly and it's a nice relaxing spot.
I even thought it was neat how all the plants have individual names! Too cute :)
author: Kate S.

description: Amazing cafe. Beautiful, clean space with a classic yet modern decor. Staff is very helpful, entertaining, witty, intelligent and fun. No loud  music blaring, so one can concentrate on reading, writing, socializing or just sitting and contemplating. My only complaint is that they're not open later during the week!
author: jen b.

description: Cute, cozy, silent and lovely place for work. Fast and good wifi connexion. The only snag is that they turn off wifi connexion at 5pm. Good bagels and good coffee. You can read all kind of magazines for free. Affordable prices. Only cash. My favorite place to work in San Francisco!
author: Laura M.

description:
Really solid 11am Sunday brunch without a line because you order at the counter and seat yourself. Really quality California eggs. The cashier was shockingly friendly and upbeat. 

Only reason for 4 stars is the place is meh on affordability.
author: Ojus P.

description:
I have to preface this with I do not like to write reviews because most places do not merit praise. But this place is an exception. What a jewel in sea of ordinary cafes that litter the Mission. The place is actually clean, well serviced and offer an array of things to eat that other cafes don't stock. They have a spicy Mexican hot chocolate!! Come on, even the Mexican restaurants don't have spicy Mexican hot chocolate! 

I like the clean painted walls, the comfortable tables and sofas, the fact that they don't have wifi that attracts mind numbing doh-doh's to sit and stare at a screen all day. People are actually talking to each other when you walk in. Amazing, right? The place oozes with social atmosphere and people come in groups to enjoy each others company! Bring a date, bring your parents, bring your niece for a cup of hot chocolate. This is one of the few places in the Mission that I'm actually rooting for to make it. Oh yeah, and if you're lonely, just pick up a sci-fi novel in the adjacent bookstore!! LOVE this place!!
author: Luis C.

description:
Perfect place to nerd out, read a new book or work in a (usually) quiet and calm environment. Best cafe in SF may be a stretch, but not by much. Almost hesitate to recommend it because its still largely a hidden gem.

Staff is awesome, food is simple, inexpensive and very good. My home away from home.
author: Jonathan K.

description:
A year later and no surprise that this cafe is doing well. I recently had one of their meat and cheese plates - it was excellent and fresh. The staff was helpful with suggesting it when I needed a savory snack, and as always they were SUPER polite (in an honest way, not that obsequious BS you get at the supermarket or Star*ucks).
Their menu is changing and growing and I love that they update it properly on the "big board" instead of just crossing out stuff or messily updating pricing.

Keep up the good work (and keep the bookstore alive if you can!)
author: Miles T.

description:
I love Borderland Books. I wanted to support the new Cafe. I really enjoy the bright lay out, revolving artists, extensive menu, and wood furniture. The chocolate cream puffs are supper nummy if you can get them.

I do not like their counter help. They want to read more than they want to serve. The smile pretty but mutter "piss off" under their breath. It's not like I can't tell you are talking sweet to me but saying piss off and die Mister. I've tried twice to get past the attitude and yet I can't.

Today's tipper was the argumentative counter help that told me "most of the people that work at the coffee shop don't drink coffee". "Yikes" I say "that's kind of scary". He countered "No, not really I mean why would we? We are around it all day." Well mister you would want to drink the coffee to know that you are creating a great beverage. Which clearly since you do not drink coffee you are not educated enough to make coffee. I can say so because the coffee you made me was so bitter and thick it needed to be tossed out; which is what happened. Sadder still the coffee was "fresh". I know I must be wacky to want a coffee shop to serve I dunno good coffee?  Why go to a restaurant where no one who makes the food, eats the food? IF no one who works there likes coffee maybe you should specialize in tea? Be a tea shop. Ditch the coffee. It's not nice to pretend.
