Last time it was the mean dude with the evil crudities. I'm allergic to belladonnas. I mentioned it when I ordered the cut vegetable plate. They barked out my complete order and there on the plate was a fist of Bell Peppers. I had not touched the plate just gestured at it and  I say "Oh I don't eat bell peppers" to the counter dude he barked "Well its illegal for me to take the plate back after I put it on the counter". WTF? That's news to me. I try and explain further my issue and he looks non pulsed and say NOT MY ISSUE and stomps off. Huh? Well in to the trash that goes. Yea wasted food and money. I heart you, you unfeeling bastard.

Please make these things better so I can patron your shop. I know the owners are good people and I want to support and like this place but I can't under these conditions.
author: Kitten M.

description: The coffee is good and the proprietor is super nice. It's fairly quiet in here -- great place to read or do some work in a relaxing atmosphere.
author: James J.

description: I was wandering this neighborhood after a visit to Paxton Gate and suddenly had low blood sugar and the need to eat immediately. I walked a bit and found Borderlands Cafe. I was happy to find that they sell black and white cookies, which I love and never find where I live. The men working the counter were friendly and helpful and the black and white cookie was delicious. I sat in a comfortable chair by a window and ate my cookie and read a magazine, which they didn't seem to mind.
author: Amy A.

description:
I love Borderlands. We've been there many times and have enjoyed the welcoming vibe. The staff is very nice. They have a wide and good selection of teas, many of which we've tried. I dunno from coffee, but plenty of people come through for coffee to go, so I imagine it can't be as bad as many on here would have you believe.  We haven't eaten much here, but it looks fine and typical of cafe offerings in SF. It's not a kitchen, so don't expect anything elaborate. Think bread and cheese plate, pastry, etc.

You know why else I love it? Because virtually all of these bad reviews are about not having wifi at night and on the weekend. They have a big sign. It's not a dirty secret. So, if you are too cheap to have your own cell signal or in a jam and need wifi, you need to go somewhere else. Just think: these bohemians are keeping all the nasty people with books and newspapers and board games out of your Starbucks. You should thank them!
author: Spaulding A.

description:
Finally! A coffeeshop where it is QUIET and you can READ and STUDY and do WORK in SILENCE!

Owned by the same folks at the bookstore next door,  Borderlands is without a doubt the coffee shop for relaxed reading and quiet meditation.

Spacious interior with calming hardwood floors and high ceilings, Borderlands has half a dozen clean and comfy sofas as well as big wooden tables and free wifi.  You know what it doesn't have? Music.  You know what else it doesn't have? Jackasses braying at one another.  I call it heaven.

They have nearly every magazine you can think of available for purchase or just free in-store reading.  The coffee and espresso and tea is of course fabulous.

It is so frustrating that there are no other coffee shops where you can take your laptop and textbook and do schoolwork, or writing, or reading.  Everywhere else is noisy and filled with obnoxious music and chatter.

Come on into Borderlands, turn your cellphone on vibrate, order a cup of coffee, pull up a desk or sofa, and use that thing floating in your skull for smart-making.
author: Brian L.

description:
I came here with some friends the other day.  I love their inviting feel.  This is not a coffee shop where every available chair is taken up by a laptop zombie.  This place invites quiet conversation, like a slightly more lively library.

I also love their association with the science-fiction heavy bookstore next store.  Also, they had a great selection of current magazines to read.  It reminded me of high school in the 90s, when the teenage activity to fight boredom in the suburbs was to hit up Border's bookstores and peruse their hundreds of periodicals for hours (for free) while drinking a $3 sugary "coffee."

But of course, the coffee and other drinks (such as mexican hot chocolate, yum!) at Borderlands are much preferred to the now extinct Border's Bookstores.
author: Kyle T.

description:
This is my office away from the office. I love how spacious, bright and simple the interior is. The draped vine plants also add a refreshing touch of life. 

I enjoy exploring their delicious tea selection, and taking brief breaks from work by perusing the latest articles in their magazine selection.

Staff is very friendly, chairs and couches are great.


Potential cons:

-wifi is from 9am-5pm, keep that in mind.
-food selection is limited, although they are currently working on a new menu... curious to see what they come up with.
-No music to diffuse sometimes loud noises from the kitchen or other patrons

Doesn't bother me
author: Carina J.

description:
Their iced black tea is PG tips!  no bitterness.  love it.

Also they were super nice about us using the bathroom - even pointed us in the direction of their attached bookstore (where the bathroom key is a legit, old school skeleton key).  

Very friendly staff.  
no wifi - perfect for those who want to be in a space without distraction.
author: Monica R.

description:
I love this cafe. No wifi, its true, but the space is quirky and contemplative, full of comfortable nooks to read your book or one of the many periodicals stacked on the shelves. 

Their snacks are perfect - the Ascetic Plate (fresh baguette, olive oil, vinegar, and olives) is our favorite. I will be honest and say the coffee is mediocre, but there are so many things to like about this place that this fact doesn't sway me. Their loose tea selection is good. 

A great place to eavesdrop on conversations of literary/creative types. Last time I was here, a creative writing group was very seriously workshopping a zombie romance piece.
author: Monica S.

description:
Great place to bring a book and hang out for a few hours.  They have both tables and a few comfy couches and oversized chairs.  The high ceilings and bright natural light make it an inviting space. 

What I love is that they have a magazine stand with magazines for sale but they let the cafe clientele read them while they are there.  I had the chai latte, which was a bit spicier and less sweet than your average chai- very tasty.
author: Elana R.

description:
I am in love with Borderlands Café. I don't even want to write this review because then more people will go. 

So why do I love it? 
1. No wi-fi. It means you can get work done without being distracted by the internet. (And I am powerless against the draw of endless news articles, Facebook, and streaming video.)

2. Practically bottomless tea. I normally get a pot of loose leaf tea when I first arrive and after I finish it off, they'll fill it up with more hot water for free. 

3. They have tasty small plates of different cheeses, meats, olives, etc. which are perfect for snacking on as you write cover letters or as you read one of their bazillion different magazines. 

4. Community feeling. The people at the counter have always been friendly, but respectful of your wish to work/read quietly. And if you find yourself sharing one of the tables with someone you don't know, it feels natural rather than uncomfortable.
author: Meredith D.
Inigo M.

description:
Ok, these people had a plan when they opened, stuck to it, and did a great job. This place has a vision of being a community hub and succeeds. Ample comfortable seating, large common tables, and always friendly service.

And it is spotlessly clean!  The got back to back 100's on the notoriously difficult SF Health Dept inspection. Did I mention it is clean? I mention this 'cause my infant daughter roams around in here all the time. And how many places do you go to in the Mission that are clean enough to eat off the floors? Seriously!, they are that finicky.

Their pastries rock, their coffee is always consistently good, their prices are reasonable, and I love that there is no wifi. They aren't Luddites here, you are perfectly welcome to bring your computer and work the day away. It is just nice to not feel wired in for a change.

Also, many events on a regular basis, and frequent tie ins to their sister store next door, Borderlands Books.
author: Bobby D.

description:
OK, objectivity: there is no wifi and for however long you stay, you'll be cut off from your phone and all outside obligations.  The good side: you'll be cut off from outside obligations, no one will be able to find you (unless they show up) while you lounge in the wooden tables and cosy velvet sofa's, reading foreign affairs, or bon appetit, goth or macrame magazines. Sunlight will spill down upon the pages and across your buttery croissant from a back window. As you sip gourmet espresso drinks, hairless cats will wander in from the adjoining sci-fi bookstore. The staff are friendly, flirtatious and approachable. Further they are bonafide bibliophiles who can be engaged in great conversations. 
(le sigh) 'Tis a dreamy little niche in the mission.
author: Dylan A.

description:
A new favorite-kind staff, excellent lattes, and a quiet (wifi-free) environment.  Big magazine collection, too...

Perusing the other reviews, I literally laughed out loud at the grumps who somehow had a bad experience.  Good riddance!  You'll probably love the Summit...
author: Daryl W.

description: Not sure what to think of this place. NO WIFI ON THE WEEKENDS. If you want to coffee up on a good book, then perfect. But if you want to surf the net? Probly not going to work out. If they want to do the no wifi thing then they should play some music. Jazz, indie, classic rock, something. Oh and the furniture is really, really nice.
author: Will D.

description: Well-lit space with a good amount of room. Usually quiet, so you can get work done. Food selection is mostly pastries, bagels, etc. Would be nice if they added more savories.
author: Lake Y.

description: I am a fan of Borderlands because I love the bookshop angle, and they are super supportive of the local writer's community.  That being said, they need to step up their game in the chocolate chip cookie department, because current offerings are not cutting it, and that's one of my main four food groups.
author: Tasha D.

description: This magical place (with a bookstore) reminds me of a Massachusetts home. It's the place I've been looking for to get my reading  and studying done. The spiced cider was warm and perfected my welcome.
author: Adrian A.

description:
Out of all the options in the area, I see no point in coming here.  

They seem to be attracting students looking for a quiet place to study.  They have a library, large tables, and the music was off.

However if you're going to invest in the coffee side of your coffee/reading lounge, you need to know how to make a coffee.

I ordered a capp for here (nearly $4).  I suspect the person who helped me and made the drink was either management or owner.  I retrieved my scorching hot drink.  It was a parched espresso shot beneath a layer of stiff bubbly foam.  So bubbly it resembled dishwater.  Overall undrinkable.
author: Annika L.

description:
GREAT: Quiet
              Good Coffee
              Great snacks
              Feels like your at home!

NOT SO GREAT: No wifi
author: Nene D.

description:
I walked in. I ordered a chai latte from unfriendly dudette. A few moments later, dude called out "chai latte." I brought it to the table and drank it. It was a latte - an espresso latte. Though I looked for it,  the chai was not to be found anywhere amid the espresso...

So I sat there and pondered my next move. It actually was a dilemma. For one thing, the dude who made the drink had called it a chai latte. I could only come up with two options: either he was bored and on autopilot (likely) or I had actually stepped into an alternate universe where chai tasted like espresso and espresso tasted like chai (admittedly less likely). In the end I decided to write the drink off like an ill-fated subprime mortgage. 

In their defense it was a delicious latte, thus the second star.
author: Travis S.

description: I just ran in for a cup of iced coffee. It looks like a cool place to hang out. It's not cozy, but it seems like a good place to study or read a magazine. The place gets lot of space and light. There is also a display of magazines that I think are available for people to read.
author: Margaret R.

description: In a world oversaturated with constant media bombardment and instant communication, Borderlands Cafe is a little oasis of quiet and zero internet. I can come here to work and read, or have a nice conversation with a friend without anyone needing to instagram or tweet a moment of it. Incredibly refreshing. Love the nerdy staff and the menu selections, especially the loose leaf tea. The place is clean and full of houseplants with names, and also tongue-in-cheek signs which provide quiet amusement. I hope they never change a thing.
author: Kay B.

description:
I love Borderlands because it has no wifi, so I can actually get work done.  It's also usually fairly quiet, and no music playing either. The place has plenty of tables and outlets, as well as couches and tons of magazines.  

My only complaint is that I wish any of the baristas actually new how to make a latte or cappuccino.
author: Amy S.

description:
Love this place. Friendly staff and an incredible selection of teas. There's a hidden room in the back facing onto the Mission playground - lots of light and plenty of tables to spread out and read, work, or study. They don't have sandwiches, but the meat and cheese plates are basically the same thing and you can share it with however many people depending on the size you order. 

The mochas tend to be on the caffeinated side, so if you want a quick sugar and caffeine boost just be forewarned!
author: Teicho S.

description: I love the look of this sunny, airy cafe. The staff were the friendliest and fast with our drinks.
author: Ellie B.

description: I always loved this place because some of the stuff is really friendly and the place itself is very nice, but there one waiter you really want to avoid. I was waiting to be served and he pretended he didn't see me for some time. I then asked him if I could have bacon and cheese without bread. He looked at me as if I was an alien and he refused to do it because he didn't know how to charge me.
author: Gina L.

description:
Another wonderfully relaxing trip to borderlands café. This time, the coffee was delightful. Small soy latté for just under $4. Deliciously frothed milk. Perfect temperature. I personally like mine a teeny bit stronger, but this is probably a great level for most. 

The lighting here is fantastic. Even in the bathroom! A warm glow without being overly yellow or bright. It almost actually makes me happy to do work here...almost. 

Service was friendly as ever. I love being greeted with an actual smile :)

I still might not make this my go to hangout-and-catch-up-with-friends place (it's suuuuper quiet, which is part of the charm), but it will definitely be high up on my list of chill, get-work-done spots.
author: Monica C.

description:
I have never written a review ...until now. Not only is it the best Mocha I have had but the guy that works here never stops smiling. He is the nicest guy who probably never has bad days. He is beyond positive which makes you feel welcome to hang around all day.

It is a quiet, clean cafe with endless tables, couches and armchairs. Tons of magazines and wonderfully quiet. I had a 30 min conference call and went outside not once worried about the saftey of my personal possessions inside. 

I don't know why it took me so long to find this spot but I am in love.
author: Britni S.

description:
This review focuses on Borderlands Cafe's hot chocolate (I'm making a Hot Hot Chocolate list)

Whoa, amazing hot chocolate. So creamy and rich. You can tell they are very skilled in steaming milk and understand milk/chocolate ratios. I'm obsessed with hot chocolate and this place offers one amazing cup!
author: Lee D.

description:
I love that there is no wifi. There are enough places to not have wifi. Also, precaution: there is terrible cel service (all carriers) as well- good for quiet, but you'll miss calls. 

I find their drinks excellent. The cappuccino and latés are much more traditional, and not the 'just fill it up with milk and make it huge' that starbucks popularized. 

They also have good snacks, and let you read the magazines if you're careful. and they have great magazines!
author: meredith b.

description:
When I first walked by this coffee shop, two things caught my eye:  how brightly lit it was, and, on the glass outside, the words "no wi-fi."  Let me explain how these two things were the reasons why I decided to trek into the Mission to study.

First, I can't stand it when I go into a coffee shop to study but there is barely enough lighting to see my books.  When I study, I like it brightly lit so I'm not straining to read; I have more than enough strain from reading my books in the first place to really want to have to worry about being able to read it in the first place.  I sat on the couch next to the windows in the back of the cafe, and it was nice to have a large coffee table to spread my study materials out on (I felt kind of bad with 30 some odd flash cards spread willy-nilly everywhere . . . :D).  I take up a lot of space when I study, and there are plenty of tables in this cafe to do that.  I saw plenty of other people studying or reading or doing work, as well.

Second, the "no wi-fi" may be a deterrent to many people in this internet-driven world, but it was actually kind of refreshing.  Like many of my fellow students who are perpetually plugged into our cyber worlds (see number of yelpers who are students), it's rare that we're ever really able to unplug and study without the internet bouncing back and forth in front of us like an unruly child tempting us with fun sites (like Yelp!).  Thus when I found a place I could go without having to worry about being tempted to check my email, I had to go.

And I found that I REALLY like it here!  Aside from the brightly lit area to be used for studying, the barista is friendly, and there isn't annoying music blasting in the background.  People generally mind their own business, but you can see that everyone is comfortable and smiles at one another.  I like that.  People should smile more.

The coffee itself-- I can't say.  I had a latte.  It was normal, I suppose.  Nothing spectacular, but I am not really a coffee person.  I'm more of a tea person-- next time I go I'll try the tea instead, I think.  Just to mix things up.

EDIT:  I forgot to mention-- I LOVE the range of their magazine collection!  I was distracted a few times by the magazines.  Art, science, fashion, etc.  Everything and anything.  I love it.
author: Jeanne Y.

description: Quaint little coffee shop attached to a bookstore. Super friendly service and nice open tables. No wifi makes it a nice place to get away from the hustle and bustle.
author: Clinton L.

description:
Love that in cafe run by a bookstore there is  no wi-fi and this techno geek wouldn't have it any other way. The space is huge, the couches and seat are comfy, the counter people are actually friendly which is a miracle in this city of too cool for school mission baristas. The selection of mags in easy to browse and it's the perfect place to read the book you just got next door at the bookstore. 

Did I mention the cute geeky folks behind the counter. let's mention them again.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
This is my new favorite neighborhood coffee shop.  Mind you, it's not for everyone.

I like that there's no Wi Fi -- it really feels like a place you can come to read, play a board game or even get to know your fellow patrons.  And if that's not your cup of tea, there are at least half a dozen coffee shops within two blocks that can cater to those wanting Wi Fi.

The staff was very friendly and the I loved the open air feel of the cafe.  It's unpretentious and welcoming in every way.

Those positive points aside, this is a cafe that is being run by a bookstore, not anyone with experience in the food industry, and thusly seems to still need a bit of refining in terms of it's food and beverage operation if they want to stick around.  

* Nearly everything takes at least 5 - 15 minutes to be prepared -- from coffee to a snack plate, be prepared to wait.  They don't appear to do any mise-en-place or food prep.

* Staff, while very friendly, doesn't seem to have experience running a cafe.  More than one customer didn't pay because the staff was too scattered to get to the register while juggling 5 other balls. They are at times understaffed and then overstaffed, with an ill-defined process for moving customers through the line.  

* If there is a line (more than 2 people waiting to order), expect there to be a disproportionately long wait to even put an order in. 

Having stated all these negatives, I still really like this cafe.  I sincerely hope that they build some process into their system (possible hire someone who has worked in the industry who can help streamline their operation) because I want to see them succeed!
author: Laura K.

description:
I like this place. Very simple, decent coffee and pastries but most of all, not too many hipsters with their annoying attitude and sense of importance.
You just go there if you feel like reading something or spend an hour or so in te old fashion way to enjoy a coffee place.
Definitely an enjoyable place.
author: Luca R.

description: The place is great, coffee OK, but pastries are so-so. I had a bad experience with one if their scones. The WiFi is absent. The service may be a little pretentious.
author: Fanette J.

description: Clean bright coffee shop.  It is very spacious inside and the tables have a good distance between them so you don't feel all cramped.
author: Mary V.

description:
to this date, this has been the most soothing place for me to write.
No obnoxious hipster music being whistled along to by sulky hipster barista....CHECK (although the barista/manager with the long hair could use some volume control)

Quirky clientele that doesn't gossip loudly or yammer on cellphones....Yep, thank you, considerate people!

Plenty of good magazines to use as a study break...their wide range lacks pretension

Good snacks--try the north beach plate with it's garlicky tomato mozzarella chunks

Loose leaf tea selection--they're always happy to refill with hot water. I love the dorky barista with her Amelia Earhart goggles :)

The back space is beautifully sunlit and shhh it gets wifi
author: Liane G.

description:
I love it here.
After I've browsed the bookstore for a good long time, I always head over to the cafe to sip some tea or Mexican hot chocolate and nibble a cookie or scone while I read.
They have a good-sized tea selection (lately I've been into the lapsang souchong), and their Mexican hot chocolate is nice and spicy, better than the one I grew up on. Drinks from the espresso bar are strong, delicious and not too sweet -a nice change from chain coffee shops. The baristas are friendly and quick without being *too* quick -they're not trying to rush you out the door, and hey, it takes time to pull a good shot of espresso.
There's always seating available (it's an extra good day if I can snag a spot on the couch!), and I'm okay with the fact that there's no Wi-Fi. Who needs it when you have a stack of new books to read, or the latest issue of Gothic Beauty? Seriously, I love Borderlands so much just for carrying that magazine. 

Bonus points: The potted plants have names. I didn't notice right away, but it's a very cute touch :)
author: Lily S.

description:
Borderlands has a no wifi policy. Kind of dig it. Retro. Apparently this is what cafes were like before the Internet:

- People talking
- Newspapers being read (that was me)
- Pictures being shared
- Spirited games of Magic: The Gathering (which as I overheard, gets people uber excited about spells, potions and some other stuff I was slightly amused by but absolutely support the passion. We're all a little quirky.)

All this was taken in while enjoying one of the most misleading in the best way possible "snack" plates of bread, turkey and veggies. I can only image how big the "meal" and "share" sizes are. Bring friends.

More comfortable seating would have been nice (the three people who scored the couch were not going anywhere) and my small latte sans syrup was ever so slightly expensive ($3.50). Neither prevent me from highly recommending. Bring a book. Your best Magic spells. Whatever works.
author: Jason B.

description: Got a coffee and a cheese danish here, after a afternoon walk and window shopping. I have to say the service was fast and very good, people there were very friendly and the environment was good to hang out. Only thing I didn't like was the taste of the coffee they served here, it was too sour!
author: Kalai L.

description: This is a great cafe to get real work done in. By real work, I mean thinking man's work. Go here when you don't want to be distracted by the interwebs because there is no wifi. It's really quiet so you can hear yourself think. The staff are super friendly (almost to disbelief) and the prices are really reasonable. I've never seen it super crowded, which is also nice. I hop around to a lot of cafes and this is one of my favorites.
author: Ramon S.

description: Bright and quiet and peaceful. A wonderful place to study or to chat (softly) with a friend.
author: Lesley P.

description: Just love this place (obviously not the only one) - really nice people at the counter, reasonable prices, it's a cafe where you aren't afraid to actually talk to other people and occasionally you even overhear a good nerdy pun :)
author: Brian K.

description: This cafe is a massive relief! Finally a cafe that is QUIET! The seating and atmosphere is very cozy, and the lack of wifi means you'll a tally find a free seat and will be happy to read for an hour or two in QUIET!  Great coffee, and a super-clean bathroom, no music, perfect lighting...thank you!
author: Elli F.

description:
Dear god I love this place. It's my new library/living room/kitchen. 

I have spent at least two hours here every day for the last two weeks. I'm not kidding. I have an excuse: I am a first year law student in finals, and I can't study at school (too much crazy nervous energy) or at home (where I can play on the internet or garden or etc.) 

Here's why this place is the best cafe ever:
1. The people are fantastic. The owner likes feedback. He thanks me for being a good customer. The baristas are (almost all) sweet and POLITE (that should be worth two stars on its own in the Mission). And it's true, they don't kick you at right at 9 pm. I like going to a place that wants to be open, but also wants its employees to get out when they are supposed to get out. 

2. The coffee is delicious and always fresh, since they don't make huge pots and leave it to sit around for hours. Also, where else can you get a delicious cup of coffee for $1.10?!

3. It is a perfect environment for anything except surfing the internet. It is comfortable for chatting or reading and, as other reviewers have mentioned, it is perfect for studying. Big tables, brightly lit without fluorescent, lots of sockets, and everyone shares space nicely.

4. Yummy food!  I love the North Beach and the Crudite (they use REALLY good olive oil), but what's even better is that the pastries are discounted in the afternoon. 

5. They introduced me to the Arnold Palmer. How did I not know the delight of lemonade and iced tea mixed together? So sad.
author: Nadya K.

description: This seems like a cute coffee shop/ hang-out place. I just got the chai, which was good, but there are food options there as well. Ambiance is bright and airy and it's attached to a sci-fi bookstore as well.
author: Ivana J.

description: I love the atmosphere of this place. It's one of my favorite hangouts on a lazy morning, with the sun coming in the tall east-facing windows, a soy cappuccino at my elbow, and a good book.
author: Amy W.

description: Really excellent spot to lounge with a hot drink while reading a book or magazine from their well-curated racks.  In nyc, i would always find myself at mcnally jackson or housing works in soho, where you could stay inside all day without being bothered.  This brings me back to that a bit.
author: Samuel H.

description: Visited for the third time yesterday, and I intend to make this a regular jaunt. Good drip coffee (with the option of pouring my own almond milk!) and one of the best chocolate croissants I've ever had (okay, so it's not light and fluffy and French, but there's a generous amount of chocolate drizzled outside and wedged inside). The atmosphere changes from the front of the store to the back. In the front - where I'm less likely to sit - there's traffic from the adjoining bookstore and customers constantly roving to and fro amongst the bite-size indie tables. In the back, there are multiple larger tables good for groups and for people who like to spread everything from their Mary Poppins backpacks (me) not to mention a few comfy chairs and couches. Finally, I had some excellent service from a young woman whose name I unfortunately didn't request. She was particularly kind and helpful with a genuineness I often find lacking in customer service professionals. Highly recommended.
author: David K.

description:
Ecco coffee served here! Yay!  Have been a fan of Ecco for many years and glad to see it being served on Valencia.

Borderlands Café is beautiful - the simplicity of the decor, the floors(!), etc.  Very nicely done.  The prices are GREAT ($1.00 for an Ecco drip?!).

Update: Well, I went back to this café yesterday and bought two lattes.  Was so excited as Ecco coffee is amongst my favorite.  I was shocked to find that the barista at Borderlands doesn't have a clue about how to make a latte!  Both were horrible!  They were essentially just warm coffee and certainly were not worth the 4.50 or so that I paid for each.  Boo!  :-(

I'll stick with Four Barrel for quality espresso drinks, but will return to Borderlands for a good drip and the pleasant ambiance.  What a shame!
author: Jon B.

description: No wifi and no music makes the environment of this spacious coffe shop a good place to work or have a conversation.
author: Erich V.

description: This is one of the nicest cafes in the city. Courteous staff, wooden interior, good drinks, and magazines for perusal. It's also reasonably quiet if you need to read or write without too many distractions. A passageway connects to a bookstore bearing the same name that is also worth exploring for its own merits. The only minor inconvenience is that Borderlands Cafe does not have wifi except under certain circumstances (as of the time of writing, they do -- though it seems temporary).
author: Giulio R.

description:
I was wandering up Valencia, trying to resist the magnetic pull of Ritual (I always have a terrible time there, yet I keep ending up there again) when suddenly there was something at the edge of my field of vision that hadn't been there before. My first impression was gorgeous light reflecting off the polished antique wood floor, huge tables, and high ceiling, making the place feel spacious and welcoming all at once.

1st star - They have a couch. 'Nuff said on that one. Try to save a seat on it for me.

2nd star - Huge, sturdy tables that would be perfect for playing games on or getting to know your neighbor which I guess is the point since they don't have wi-fi (though they didn't mind me using my computer to do work).

3rd star - The friendliest, most enthusiastic guy in the world works here. You can tell he is so excited and a little nervous for this new project to work out. He was super-accommodating of all my little requests and changes and was just the right blend of chattiness and leaving me alone to get stuff done.

4th star - I had a mocha and it was fantastic - very hot, well-balanced flavors, great head of foam even though it was soy. The first few days of a new coffee shop are the critical period to analyze their coffee drinks, because the cafe's overarching vision either prioritizes coffee, in which case they'll hire employees who actually know how to make it, or prioritizes atmosphere/food/music/something that's not coffee, in which case they'll hire attractive young people and show them how to press the buttons on the coffee machines.

5th star - Their food menu is not like any other cafe menu in the neighborhood. They offer several different "plates" (meat & cheese; crudites & something else; tomato, mozarella, & olives; etc., all with bread alongside) and offer them in several sizes - I think snack, meal, and to share. The snack plates are literally $3 or $4 dollars, which is great when you need a little something to tide you over while you get some work done but you don't want to throw down for a whole meal/sandwich. Basically it's like getting a bagel, but you get to eat something that's not a bagel!

Things to consider: Not many vegan options on the food menu, (definitely not many gluten-free options, but they accommodated me admirably in letting my make up my own plate and I just don't expect to see GF offerings on menus) and I hope they can survive without offering wi-fi. It's like I can't even remember anymore why we used to go to coffeshops before the days when we all had laptops and they all offered wireless...
author: Scrumptious S.

description:
Finally! A quiet, quiet, quiet coffee shop where you can read and do paperwork without any thumping music or obnoxious chatter.

Beautiful wood floors and every published magazine available for free browsing or purchase.

Giant comfy sofas, large wooden tables and desks to spread appers out on, and clean, clean, clean.

Very quality espresso and neat little meat and fruit plates available.  Clean bathrooms and friendly staff.

Five stars.
author: C H.

description: Great coffee, a selection of magazines to peruse through, Free Wifi and they have bagels!
author: N Y.

description:
I, too, walk past other well-known mission coffee institutions to go to borderlands. i love the fact that in a 'hood that can often be riddled with pretentious hipsters, there is a cafe with awesome coffee (intelligentsia), big tables, and nice staff. 
no internet means people are willing to interact with one another and i'm less distracted when trying to get my writing done. 
my two wishes for this place would be: later hours (but that's my wish for pretty much EVERYWHERE in sf) and outside seating, but overall a great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Ellen S.

description:
FINALLY a decent cafe on this block. (Javalencia and Mission Creek aren't cutting it.)

- Interesting selection of teas, including loose leaf. I LOVE that they give me the teapot with strainer and a little tray for it. That's the way it should be done everywhere.
- Entertaining names for their dessert plates which come in two sizes: Modest ($5) and Immodest ($8)
- Comfy, quiet place with couches and large tables
- sadly has no wifi, but a great place nonetheless. I can understand they don't want laptoppers camping out for too long.
author: Kelly R.

description:
TRY THIS PLACE - u will love it!  

One of the best cafes I've been to - beautiful, yet comfy decor: hardwood floors, stylish comfy leather couches and ample seating, spacious, friendly staff, good (lite) eats and beverages.  Tea is excellent, prices reasonable, quiet, AND . . . a bookstore to peruse!
Enjoy!
LuLu, Richmond, CA
author: Lulu L.

description:
Last time I was here my friend and I split the North Beach plate, the 'to share' size. It was a lovely plate with bread, caprese salad and salami, and it filled us up quite nicely.
I will definitely be back for the snacks!
author: Rachel M.

description:
I am in heaven.  I am sitting at a long polished red wood table waiting for the Writing Marathon to start.  I am sipping coffee that I finished at a quaint stand with everything anyone could want in a tea or coffee beverage available from soy to agave.  The art on the walls is attached to the artist.  I strolled past the connected entrance to Borderland Books, which beaconed with shelves of new surprises.  A full rack of magazines like the ones I have spent hours in front of at airports, kicking my wheelie bag along as I picked a new magazine.  The décor, the look, the feel of this place is classic lover of literature quaint and I love it.  I am looking across a cozy alcove in the back with a fluffy couch and chairs that beg for passionate conversation about why the world is going to hell in a Prada bag.  This is the spot to meet someone for coffee.  CASH only and no wireless, but plenty of plugs for writers like me who need to stop surfing the internet and get something done.

This review was written from my T-Mobile Hotspot while drinking my coffee and eating a beautiful and delicious cranberry muffin.  I cheated
author: Robin T.

description:
Great potted tea selection and best Mexican hot chocolate I've had in SF--not too sweet and with a nice peppery finish. The way it is supposed to be, in my opinion.

Also, they are very, very responsive and open to feedback. If something wasn't quite right, or you think might be better if done another way, let them know. I know from watching how they run Borderlands Bookstore next door (Which you should also visit! Grab a book and read it while you sip your drink) that they care about quality and getting things right!
author: Laura and Dan B.

description: Great old library atmosphere, very calm, next to the bookstore. A neat place to just read and sip on a delicious raspberry lemonade.
author: Johann R.

description: I stopped by Borderlands today while I was in Dolores Park and looking to avoid the porta-potties by buying a coffee. Borderlands doesn't try to be trendy and its visitors certainly don't go there for the ambiance. I ordered an americano and the staff were friendly, but the americano was really weak and all their milk pitchers were empty. Kind of a bummer. There's better coffeeshops in the Mission, I will walk further next time to get to one!
author: K M.

description:
My friend and I have been on a quest to find the perfect cafe for us to work and chat about our stories. Borderlands Cafe is it. It's kind of perfect. Huge range of sci-fi, fantasy novels, graphic novels next door for inspiration and then inexpensive beverages, snack platters in the cafe. I also love the apple spice cider. We share a big pot of earl grey for hours and get SO MUCH work done. They kindly refilled our teapot many times. Interestingly, the no wifi policy does this cafe's patrons a great service and maintains a very calm and comfortably peopled atmosphere.

The tables are so spacious for me to pile my books, reference material, notebook and sketchbook. The atmosphere is truly peaceful and clean. A lot of time the quiet chatter you will hear is from others discussing their own creative work and what not. I really like that the customers preserve the great atmosphere of the cafe.  We like the back of the cafe best but have found every table to be its own placid island.

It seems like you can even reserve tables for writing meetings and whatnot. More proof that this is a true writer's cafe.

The staff are always so polite, sweet, patient and attentive.  We've decided to designate every free Monday as our writing-work day at Borderlands.
author: E L.

description:
$1.10 for a cup of coffee.
The place is clean and the floorplan is open so you don't feel as though you are on top of the other patrons.
The gentleman behind the counter was very helpful and kind.
I will definitely be back and will bring my wife next time.
author: Adam B.

description: The environment is really unwelcoming with furniture that looks country suburban.  There are signs everywhere telling you what to do and what not to touch.  It just feels wrong- can't even remember the coffee because the space is so uncomfortable.  I hope they change it up because the location is great with a ton of competition.
author: K W.

description:
I found this place by chance two weeks and I have gone back five more times. And I will come back many more times for sure. 

I like the fact that it is comfortable, the people working are friendly [rare occurrence] and the patrons do not look your usual San Francisco "cool, trendy, I'm better-than-chocolate" [if that is ever possible] crowd. I love the fact that the place invites to read, they have a great selection of magazines and I could sit for an hour and a half with a coffe for $1.64. The no WiFi is fine with me, I go there to read not surf the web.
author: Sonia E.

description:
A beautiful new café on Valencia St. Why another café on this street? Borderlands is adjunct to Borderlands Books, a high quality bookshop featuring fantasty, scifi and horror titles. This café distinguishes itself with very affordable coffee drinks, and an unequaled beautiful interior that features a gorgeous, restored wood floor and big tables. There is also a unique feature you don't see anywhere else, rows and rows of vintage scifi and fantasy pocketbooks that can be had for the paltry sum of fifty cents each - even cheaper by the dozen! 

This is a great place to socialize with your friends or read a book ~ it's not intended as an office space to be filled with laptops, hence no wifi.
author: Branford F.

description:
unfortunately they decided to open a cafe *next door* to the bookstore and since the opening they only employ former disgruntled post-office clerks. Every time I go though it seems they have just recently hired the person who is ringing me up and who clearly has not ever seen a mac before (its a MAC p.o.s. system the drinks practically ring themselves up!!) also, apparently making a pot of coffee is a really hard thing as it took 3 people to make a fresh one the last time i was there. like i said stick to the books and movies stay away from food service.

i do have to agree one point interesting food choices/options. definitely original, not very fresh (I've tasted chewier hockey pucks than the cheese danish I bought from their pretty display).

Maybe if they actually hired people who like other people and who can multitask. Humble suggestions from someone who really wanted to like this place. I keep going back hoping that the surly aging goth boy with the long hair is gone, one can only hope that they improve with time.
author: Arielle M.

description: A nice, spacious, quiet cafe. They had some interesting menu items like the salami plate. Their coffee is nothing to write home about. Compared to Ritual Roasters, which had a line down the block, this is a nice calm retreat to sit with friends, read, or get some work done.
author: Jordan P.

description: I love this place... it's like Nirvana when one wants some quiet, sunny space with some good coffee and bagel. The cute and witty employees put a smile on my face :)
author: Cooper S.

description:
Preliminary review:
Having recently discovered Borderlands Books next door I figured I would hike over and give the cafe a try for my usual Sunday afternoon reading.  The decor is great; lots of light, airy, natural wood.  Not a lot of seating.  They are clearly new to the cafe game (and say as much with a sign at the register - hey at least they're honest) but I'm hoping they'll get the hang of it.  No Wi-Fi: I didn't honestly notice as I didn't have my laptop with me that day. Well, it'll give the self-righteous neoLuddites something to crow about but if I'm going to do laptop work I probably wouldn't schlep all the way over here anyway so no skin off my nose.  The food menu looked interesting but I stuck with coffee (which was fine) this visit.
author: John S.

description:
Some of the most arrogant service I have ever been exposed to.  My friend and I walk in the store, we're carrying drinks we'd been drinking from another establishment.  After putting our things at a table (many, but not all tables were used, and not a busy time of night), I get up to order some tea to patronize the cafe.

The manager asks me if my friend will be having anything.  I told him she wouldn't -- after which he tells me that he "can't let us sit at a table if all we're ordering is a $2.25 cent tea."

Excuse me, but ordering a drink and sitting at a table is the purpose of a cafe - some will even sit for a long time with 1 drink.  Well, the jackass with no business sense lost his chance at customers or repeat customers, as we obviously didn't stay.  I can't describe how irritating it is to be smugly told to leave by an arrogant prick like that, and there's no chance I'll give this place another shot.

***

In response to Alan's comment:  

Alan, unfortunately, your defense of your behavior on Saturday reveals it to be based on your own defensive and somewhat paranoid attitude towards your customers. 

1.  We headed to the smallest open table, which happened to be towards the rear of the cafe.  There was no attempt to be circumspect, and I promptly  went to the front to order something from your cafe.

2. No, I don't take it as a given that one cannot bring a drink into a cafe.  Would you have been happier if we ordered two cookies?  I did actually want tea, so I ordered tea.  And I consider the explicit polite behavior in a cafe on the part of a customer to be to order something.  After that, it's really none of your business.

3. There really is no reasonable argument for the aggressive way in which you couched your refusal to serve us.  If you had a policy about outside drinks and cared to tell me that, i could've respected that.  If you had a policy about $5 minimums, I could've respected that.  If you had a policy about every customer ordering something, that would've been fine.  You just made up your policy on the spot after assuming the worst about a paying customer.  That's terrible service.

4.  Here's what I recommend you do in the future if you want to retain customers:

a. IF you feel its important to use draconian policies, post them explicitly or have the guts to state them explicitly and fairly.

b. Even better, keep things vague, but start by politely asking people to order more, or expressing your anger that we brought soft drinks into your cafe - maybe if you'd been up front we could've worked out a mutually agreeable solution.

c. When in doubt, don't nitpick over whether a customer is paying you $2 or $5 for a seat at a table.  You may find that the customer likes your tea, likes the ambiance, and decides to write their dissertation sitting on your couches, drinking cup after cup in the future.  Instead, you get no $, one pissed off neighbor, and an accurate, fair, and negative review on yelp.  

Good luck in the future with your business.

Ben
author: Ben M.

description:
I very much appreciate the friendly staff here.  Their meat and cheese plates are generous, the scone I got was ginormous and tasty, and the strawberry lemonade is delicious.  The atmosphere is quiet but friendly and they often have nice artwork on display.

I did not see their hours posted on their door; I wish they would post them . They were open to feedback when I suggested some improvements for the restroom like a coat hook on the door and a mirror above the sink.
author: Susie S.

description: The cleanest cafe in San Francisco, period.  The light was inviting, the mocha was delicious, the ginger cookie was delicious, and the place was quiet like a hushed library kind of quiet.  AND...no wi-fi, so I can go in there and write analog style and no one gives a care.  The staff is friendly and there are humorous little signs everywhere that tell you that the staff has a great sense of humor and humanity.  Best sign, "Your cell phone conversation is best enjoyed outside of the cafe."  LOVE IT.
author: Jo S.

description: Very nice atmosphere for working or reading on a couch or at a table. No Wi-fi. Great selection of magazines, which are free to use. Very nice staff.
author: Stephen V.

description:
best place ever to have a cup of coffee or such and sit and read. they also have lots and lots of magazines you can brows and read while you hang out.
the couches and table very comfy
and delicious large plates of bread and cheese / salami / olives etc
author: michael d.

description:
This review is for a customer service experience I had. 

Indulge me a moment to be petty...

I ordered and paid for an iced tea. $2.19 after all said and done. That's fine. But considering it was iced tea I assumed (wrongly) that there would be free refills. 

So when I went back up to the counter the girl asked me if I wanted a refill.  I said yes. She filled it up and said it would be $2.19. 

Awkward moment. 

I told her that I thought there were free refills. She said (awkwardly but polite) that it doesn't say that on the menu. 

True. But I challenge you to find me a place that does give free refills for iced tea that has a menu that says free refills for iced tea. 


I questioned them a bit saying that it was just iced tea. Because, come on, this tea was not the same as artisanal coffee or even tea hand picked by monks in the pyrenees. And if they do use a special artisanal tea then save yourself some money and buy Lipton's. Because it tastes the same. 

But that's neither here nor there.

After another awkward moment where I was waiting for them to say something other than "two-nineteen" I handed over the money and took my iced tea and walked away. 

So I made a mistake. A wrong assumption. And I guess I was waiting for them to say "hey, we understand, you made a mistake. It happens. Have this one for free. But know in the future that refills cost $2.19." 

That would have been kind, polite and it would have been good business. 

 But they didn't say that. And it cost them a customer. I meet with a friend once a week. We've been going to Borderlands. Guess what? We're not going there anymore. 

I know, it sounds petty, even to me. But it hurt. Way down deep inside. Where I'm soft. Like a woman. 

So you got my $2.19 this week (well, $4.38). But you're missing out on the other 50 weeks of the year that I meet my friend. And you will be. Because I'll be looking for a new place among the other 50 coffee shops in the area.

But this is all in the interest of feedback. I learned something. From now on, everywhere I go, I will always be skeptical and ask ahead of time if I get free refills on iced tea. So thanks for that! 

I do want to say though they were very sweet about it (as sweet as a shrug and a "sorry" can be). Just not very smart about it.
author: C h.

description: Cool little spot to grab a tea and read with your headphones. Its quiet, clean and bright. (And conveniently located across the Phoenix so you can grab a beer after you're done reading.
author: Analisa S.

description: Thrice now I have visited Borderlands Cafe for San Francisco Tarot Cafe. Jude and the gang are very accommodating and patient with our group. She sets out a plaque to reserve our table and brings our refreshments to us. No one ever whines about the noise level of our chatty bunch. We exist among the sunlight filtering in through the windows and the green plants growing in pots on the tables.
author: Camille K.

description:
Like many fans of the attached bookstore, I waited a long time for this cafe to open. And now that it is open, I have become a fan of the cafe, as well. Which is not to say that my review should be discounted because of bias. 

The No Wi-Fi policy is a refreshing concept. I like the good intent behind it --- originally, the cafe founders wanted to create a community spirit. Certainly, the cafe loses customers because of the policy. But I've seen many customers still show up with their laptops. While the intent of the policy may have been a bit high-minded --- for example, I like the tabletop signs that politely suggest we all have a neighborly attitude, but let's get real: I've encountered customers sitting at the communal tables who don't exactly have the community spirit --- the No Wi-Fi policy proves that this cafe is still legitimate, and perhaps even moreso than others. Like me, people still go to Borderlands with their laptops, if only to do work without the distraction of going on the internet.

As of this writing, the owners are still posting an apology at the cash register in regards to their "slow" service. I am amused. No, the service is not a rapid as what you get at Starbucks, but then again, THIS IS NOT STARBUCKS. This is a locally-owned small business with a community spirit at its core. Folks who come here looking for a quick fix will be sorely disappointed. This is a place where community and commercialism blend harmoniously. This is a place where you can read a novel, write the Great American Novel, and not feel out of place. This place is the real deal.

Notes

Borderlands Cafe takes debit and charge cards. 

The pastry selections are revolving and limited. Generally, the pickings thin out by late afternoon. 

I highly recommend their meat and cheese plate, which is their substitute for selling sandwiches. If you are a vegetarian, they have an equivalent plate, which I have not tried, but I have spied and it looks as appetizing as its meat counterpart. 

There are many places to sit, but weekends are busiest. 

The cafe is sometimes closed for private events, but a sign will be posted to let you know. 

Occasionally, the cafe remains open for special events, like one weekend when the bookstore had a sidewalk sale. Sometimes, board gamers come into the store and take up one or two tables. I have seen a book club or two meet here as well. Generally, expect lively traffic on the weekends.
author: Joseph R.

description: If you are looking for a nice, quiet cafe, this is the place.  Spacious, airy and sunny.  Free magazines for customers to read too!
author: marcie v.

description:
I love a cafe where I can seat to do my work or reading for hours on end and not get the stink eye from the employees for staying too long.
The pastries are delicious and the coffee really good.
They have tons of magazines that you can read and return to the shelves. So nice!
There is no internet, but I like to be able to be in a comfy place where I can concentrate and ignore all my networked social obligations.
The staff are sweet and smart, and the overall vibe is completely unpretentious. 
Yes, unpretentious in the heart of the mission.
Sounds like a dream, but it is true.
author: M D.

description: My boyfriend is the sci-fi/fantasy reader, not me, and he likes to go to Borderlands bookstore every week.  Seriously.  This was a problem for me until they opened the cafe.  Hurrah!  Great coffee, great bagels and pastries.  But the best part?  NO WI-FI.  Second best part?  NO MUSIC.  If you want to work on your laptop, fine, but if you need to be connected to live, go to Ritual and hog a table all day.  It's so relaxing to sit somewhere quiet where people actually chat (and not on their phones).  Ahhhhh.....
author: Barbara C.

description: This is my new favorite study spot. I've been looking for a good place to study for a while, one where it isn't too loud and distracting, that is relatively easy to get to, and where I feel comfortable. I love Borderlands because it is quiet, comfortable, and CLEAN. It doesn't have the sterile feeling of a library, but it does have a great atmosphere for studying. My only complaint is that they have a very small food selection. A few more items on their menu would do the trick.
author: Sheigla A.

description: I stumbled upon this cafe while walking about the Mission and am so glad to have found it!  It is a great place to sit and relax and contemplate the awesomeness of your coffee or tea.  I like the idea of another reviewer of staying open a little later.  Looking forward to returning...
author: Miranda O.

description:
I just had some kick ass soup here, and it was like three bucks.
I'm not usually one to rave about soup but this was freaking amazing, I almost want another, but that would be silly.

I had some mint jasmine green tea too and it was just what the doctor ordered.

The place just opened -you can tell the funky old wood floors were finished days ago. I almost don't want the place to get discovered, but there's plenty of room and no wifi so I imagine discovery won't wreck the place. Its attached to the borderlands bookstore which is convenient if you like that sort of thing.
author: Joe S.

description: Sipping coffee here at 8:30 a.m. on a rainy Sunday felt like being in a friend's kitchen or living room. It was quiet, well-lit, comfortable, no frills, homey, spacious.  Really liked it, will come back.
author: Mandy H.

description:
I've never seen anyone so concerned about a bagel.
A woman yelled, "poppy seed bagel with cream cheese!" loudly for a third time after receiving no response. She had the kind of worried look a mother has when they lose their child at the county fair. She emerged from behind the counter and paced the length of the cafe trying to recognize the person who had ordered the poppy seed bagel with cream cheese, but had no success and returned to her station looking more worried than ever. She consulted her colleagues and three different people were now involved in the situation. One of them, decidedly more cool and collected, once again announced in an unperturbed tone, "poppy seed bagel with cream cheese..." in stark contrast to the frantic tone that the original person was using. 
Eventually, the woman who had ordered the poppy seed bagel with cream cheese heard their call and casually walked up to the counter completely unaware of all the trouble that the staff had gone through to get her attention.

The people who work here are all very good. They are nerds, which is no surprise because the place is attached to a science fiction bookstore. I've never seen such a concentration of nerds in one place in the Mission. These are real nerds too, not fake ones who like to call themselves nerds because they were thick framed glasses and read Foucault. Nerds don't read Foucault. They read Piers Anthony, and I'm sure the entire staff at this establishment is very very familiar with Piers Anthony. I felt a sort of camaraderie with the people working there because I too used to be a nerd. It's true that since then I've started reading things like Foucault and now sport thick framed glasses, but deep in my core I'm still a nerd, and proud to be so.
A quality that all these nerds share is a sense of duty to complete the task assigned to them, faithfully, throughly. These are virtues that were no doubt passed on to them by the heros and heroines of the books they read. In the context of a cafe it makes for a very considerate and helpful staff as the scene I retold at the beginning of this review demonstrates. These people actually give a shit. When you go to most cafes in the mission the staff, whether or not they are competent in their role, at the very least seem completely aloof and uninterested. This isn't the case at Borderlands, every single person working there that I observed this morning was without exception extremely dedicated. Personally, I don't care whether the staff is interested or not as long as they get me what I want, but I was still extremely impressed by the people working at Borderlands.

The atmosphere of the place is unique too. There is no music, which makes for less distraction (I'd be horrified to hear what these nerds listen to anyway...). There's also no wi-fi which avoids the annoying high-tech crowd that go to other cafes, like The Summit. Pretty much it's a place for people go to read, write or to enjoy quiet conversation with one another, and I think that's swell. Every time I've been there I've always found a place to sit, and there are a lot of couches which I've always preferred to chairs. 

Highly recommended.
author: David V.

description: Love the concept. The homey feel it has (esp the homemade lemonade.)
author: Lisa L.

description:
NO Wi-Fi or internet. But is OK because is a bookstore type of cafe. I found myself going there often to study because they have large tables and is always clean. 
Coffee very good and they also sell food.
author: Geena T.

description: Borderlands Café feels like home to me. It's a peaceful place to read or get some work done. No music nor loud folks. The magazines are a big treat. The only down side is their hot chocolate. It's way too sweet.
author: Rosana S.

description: good coffee, good snack foods like prosciutto and cheese plates. nice place to work and people watch. not the best place to chat as it does get quiet and there's no music. could use some music played at a low level.
author: p f.

description: I really love this place! It's quiet and I always can get my homework done here. The wi-fi free environment makes me concentrate on what I need to do. I had a Raspberry Iced Tea here and it was perfect. I would recommend this place to anyone who needs a calm place to relax.
author: Ankita S.

description:
i was excited to see another quality cafe pop up in my 'hood, only this one is different in a few pretty cool ways.  they actually advertise"no wi-fi" on storefront, so you know this place is all about enjoying some brew with your homies whilst perusing cool postcards, popular magazines, or used sci-fi books.  it would be even cooler if they had some board games there........maybe i will donate my extra set of Trivial Pursuit Genus Edition.

very nice furniture, plenty of room for everyone.  the menu (and fancy pastries) looked delicious, but today was just about the coffee.  i had an au lait, which was tasty.  pricing and staff were delightful!

i look forward to spending some quality time here.
author: Aimee B.

description: Extraordinarily friendly service. This is a very peaceful place to sit. It's sunny and quiet (no music), and not pretentious in the least.The coffee is good but the food menu leaves a lot to be desired.
author: Sophia L.

description: I love it. Friendly people, friendly employees, big tables you can actually spread out on, nice coffee, and NO WIFI. Amazing for students, or people who actually want to focus.
author: Shayna K.

description: I love this place - tons of light and space, friendly staff, comfy seating and good coffee and snacks. The lack of wi-fi is the good news / bad news, as it keeps it from being another place with a sea of non-talkers behind laptops.
author: Kristine Kris C.

description: The free access to magazines is awesome. The people who work here are insanely nerdy, and I try to love them for it, though sometimes I don't. The coffee is just ok and the baked good are uninspiring, but I would eat and drink much worse for the right to work on my computer without any distraction from the internet. Thank you, Borderlands, for saving me from myself.
author: George L.

description: Just don't breathe too loud otherwise you might distract someone (kidding!)  I liked this place because sometimes in the hustle and bustle of the city it's nice to sit in a quiet cafe with a nice pot of hot blood orange tea.
author: Josie C.

description:
im all in favor of bookstore/cafe tandem, and borderlands is NOW one of them. i looved the bookstore even before the cafe opened last dec.09, and im diggin' the cafe that was opened next door, under the same umbrella. 

the cafe is very sharp and nice so far, hopefully it'll stay the same (though it's in the mission, so i will expect something farfetched). borderlands have established their reputation for being one of the go-to bookstore, and im wishing that the cafe would get the same reception in the years to come.

oh ya, one odd of the bunch in the cafe's menu..there's this hot coco that you can get as a regular OR fancy. i didnt know that there's such thing as a fancy coco, but i would be willing to try that later and give you my take on the fanciness of it. HAHAHHA
author: Marc K.

description: Cozy, well lit cafe with good selection of magazines to browse through and buy. No wi-fi allows it a sense of contemplation and perusal without the distractions of the world wide web. Still some computer users blacking away but overall an excellent shop.
author: Gregory H.

description:
It was too quiet.  Way too quiet.

The staff was nice.  Way too nice.

I want a coffee shop vibe, not a waiting-room-at-a-holistic-medicine-doctor's-office vibe.

My soy chai latte was yummy but next time I'm taking it to go.
author: Scarlett S.

description: Went here recently for the first time and found it completely adorable and charming.  A beautifully designed cafe with a great studious, hipster vibe.  I love all the different and wide-ranging periodicals that line the walls.  Good food and coffee, though the food is a bit pricey perhaps.  Met here with my writing group and it was very conducive to writing!
author: Laurel K.

description:
My favorite cafe in the mission. I like that it's peaceful, with no music, which does seem to inspire people to talk quietly (Of course, conversation in a cafe is cool, but this one successfully inspires a quiet atmosphere). It's nice and sunny and well-lit without being harsh on the eyes.

The drip coffee is incredibly strong. The food is simple, the meals and snacks are pretty good- my one gripe is the pastries are not so great, especially the sweet ones.

And the no wireless means I can come here and get some writing done - I like the studious atmosphere, it become a little like a co-working space in a nice way, but with plenty of social moments too.

The magazine selection is a little weak on the fashion & design and literary side of things, but that probably helps me get more work done.

I would like them to be open later too!
author: La M.

description:
Borderlands has the same neighborhood quality as java supreme with different offerings and a strong borderlands feel.  It's a wonderful expansion of a key community business and a great place to read a magazine or play a game with a friend or grab a snack.

amazing job folks. Especially the sign explaining the importance of waiting for coffee.  Pure awesomesauce. 

I should ding ya for the no wifi, but oh well.  Better for my health to not do work on the weekends.
author: bri b.

description: "no wi-fi" is proudly painted right next to the entrance.  This, along with a comfy couch and a small collection of books for sale signifies that this is a place for reading and conversation. A great selection of teas, nice staff, ample light and a nice view of Valencia street earn this cafe four stars in my book.
author: David G.

description:
I love this place.  Borderlands Cafe is the perfect place to read, write, or study: it's quiet, has a lovely polished wood interior, and best of all they DON'T have wireless, so nobody hunkers down at a table for hours on end.  Their employees are always cordial, never surly or holier-than-thou.

Oh, and their (perfectly decent) house coffee can be had for a buck.  One dollar!
author: Yoshi S.

description: One of my favorite cafes in the Mission and my go-to place when I want to write without distraction.  There's no wi-fi, so don't bother coming if you need it.  But it's spacious, relatively quiet, and the coffee and teas are fantastic.  A bit on the pricey side for coffee and tea, but I just think about it as paying for peace and quiet.
author: Courtney N.

description:
I really wish I could like this cafe, but I can't. It's cavernous and an echo chamber. Constant sound of dishes rattling and clacking, not to mention the bathroom door slamming constantly. 

 And, That has got to be consistently the worst coffee I've ever had.
author: Ava S.

description:
Well...as a long time patron of the bookstore, I've been waiting (im)patiently for this cafe to open.  I was privileged to see it at different points in its transformation from trash pit to elegant calm space, and the wait has been worth it.  The owners, given the work and time they have put into this space, are definitely in it for the long haul, and to help give value and energy to the neighborhood.  MUCH nicer than any chain place could ever be

It's in its learning curve - but the staff gets better every day, the owners pitch in, the Mexican coffee is to die for, and the ambiance is just perfect.  I love that there's no wi-fi - head to Starbucks if you want an office away from home - because it means its the perfect place to order a pastry and a cup of tea, or a small plate and Italian soda, and sit with your book, and disappear into another world for a little while.

I'm already thinking of this as my local...I hope that others find it too.  They are also offering a full slate of magazines catering to a ton of tastes, and unusual greeting cards.  I love that it's a community for the community, and welcomes anyone who comes in.  I like a place you can walk in and they definitely know your name.  Give them a little time, and they'll know exactly what you want to order too.
author: R.B. W.

description: Stopped in with a friend to talk and was impressed by the layout and friendliness of the owner(?). Nice layout, beautiful floor and good vibes. it was nice to be in a place that didn't surround you with laptops. Saturday afternoon and decent crowd but we were able to find a table to ourselves. Will definitely be back.
author: Derek H.

description: This brand new cafe is clean and modern without being too trendy, their small coffee is a dollar and pots are rebrewed every 30 minutes, their couch is comfy, their baristas are accommodating, their milk/sugar bar is one of the nicest and best stocked, and their muffins are great (danishes not as much).  An absolutely wonderful place to meet up with a friend or get some reading done. Thank god for a wifi free zone on valencia.
author: marisa e.

description: Walked into this place this afternoon just because I was enjoying a conversation with someone I'd just met and we needed a place to talk. SHAZAM!! clean, brightly-lit, SILENT OASIS OF CALM (barista apologized that their music system was broken-YAYY!). And now I read here that there is NO WI-FI! I love it even more. Never noticed that NOT having wi-fi is an advantage! Imagine. Big sturdy tables to spread out on. Felt like going into a friend's huge back kitchen. This place is now a destination for me. I love the concept. Oh, did I mention how QUIET it was and that I could actually HEAR what the other person was saying? WHAT A CONCEPT!!!!!!!
author: Adam D.

description: Living in the mission for a month and stopped by this place to check it out...GREAT environment for reading, studying, working on your laptop or just straight chilling.  LOVE the environment and a huge huge huge magazine selection!  Latte was absolutely delicious, though we later figured out maybe it was so smooth and delicious because it had more skim milk (our request) than actual espresso.  Didn't give us the jolt we wanted, but was sooo tasty.  The chocolate croissants are to die for!
author: Christina C.

description: A gorgeous cafe right next door to the bookstore I've loved for years - brilliant!  Thanks to the no wifi policy it was an oasis of calm and didn't have that coffee shop as office vibe so many other places exude.  They also have generous portion sizes and excellent prices.
author: Deborah K.

description: Borderlands Café is charming and pretty. It's well-lit, clean, has comfortable couches, and large tables. Since it doesn't have music or wi-fi, it's the perfect place to study or read a book. The tea is lovely and the baristas are unfailingly friendly. I love Borderlands, and I've been going at least four or five times a week since a sci-fi author's reading & book-signing I attended a few months ago.
author: Morgiriah F.

description: This was probably the worst coffee shop I have ever been to in my life. The food is terrible, the other customers look like they are seriously depressed, the baristas have a terrible attitude and no wifi!! And at each table there are signs saying not to use your cell phone indoors. I could understand if they wanted to keep a certain noise level but how is that possible when the baristas are the ones making all the noise? Walking into Borderlands Café was a huge mistake!! It was a waste of my $2.00!!
author: Lynne C.

description: I LOVE this place.  It's so quiet and lovely and the people are super nice (and tasty, tasty food).  My new fave place to meet and work...and good for breaking my wifi addiction...And the plants all have names...
author: Littles F.

description: I truly have begun an affair with this cafe. For starters, I'd just like to request to the caffeine gods that they remain open later. At any rate, they have fantastic service, great tea & coffee selections and awesome lighting. This is a definite place to be when trying to escape from the unnecessary noise level at other cafes. If you're a college student needing an extra boost I recommend their depth charge!
author: Jamie S.

description:
this place is so beautiful inside -- i love the floors, the clean design and all the nice, solid tables for working and sitting. i love the lack of wifi. people were interacting and i was way more productive than in most coffeeshops.

the tea is great. and i loved the north beach plate! fresh focaccia, olives and a bowl of tomato, mozzarella salad with fresh garlic and basil. delicious and a good deal. 

my new haunt.
author: ceecee m.

description: I love this place! It's so...civilized. Like walking into someone's living room. Quiet, with a really nice calm feel. Great for writing or doing something where you need to focus, or for a group meeting (nice big tables in the back!). Great coffee, really great snacks, and the nicest people behind the counter! My new favorite cafe.
author: Erika K.

description: I really like this place. That's right, it has no Wi-Fi, but good for them. Instead they have magazines--actual magazines--that you can read for free, and couches where you can, you know, talk to people or read a book. The people are friendly, the space is fantastic, and the coffee ain't bad.
author: Lester D.

description: Great new cafe in the hood.  Love the SF books for 50 cents!!!  Actually like that they have tried to be different by not offering Wi-Fi.  I only hope they get enough traffic to keep it going.   I tried the coffee this morning...very nice.
author: Michael T.

description: I generally go to cafés to work on my computer, and this place gets an A+ for tablespace. There's also a couple of couches for people who like to recline. The place feels well-lit and airy. It's just too bad I paid $5 for a hot chocolate! $5.20 actually. Size small, nothing special. And there's not even a wireless connection. I like this place, but I'm not getting enough value to make it a regular hot. Back to Muddy's or Ritual for me.
author: Adelle M.
